[[File:Affinity wall.png|thumb|Affinity wall diagram]] The '''affinity diagram''' is a business tool used to organize ideas and data. It is one of the [[Seven Management and Planning Tools]]. People have been grouping data into groups based on natural relationships for thousands of years; however, the term affinity diagram was devised by [[Jiro Kawakita]] in the 1960s<ref>Improving Performance Through Statistical Thinking By Galen C. Britz</ref> and is sometimes referred to as the '''KJ Method'''.
The tool is commonly used within [[project management]] and allows large numbers of ideas stemming from [[brainstorming]]<ref>[http://www.pmhut.com/affinity-diagram-kawakita-jiro-or-kj-method Affinity Diagram - Kawakita Jiro or KJ Method], Retrieved June 6, 2010</ref> to be sorted into groups, based on their natural relationships, for review and analysis.<ref>[http://www.leanyourcompany.com/methods/Using-Affinity-Diagrams.asp Using Affinity Diagrams to make sense from brainstorming]</ref> It is also frequently used in [[contextual inquiry]] as a way to organize notes and insights from field interviews. It can also be used for organizing other freeform comments, such as open-ended survey responses, support call logs, or other qualitative data.
==Process== The affinity diagram organizes ideas with following steps: # Record each idea on cards or notes. # Look for ideas that seem to be related. # Sort cards into groups until all cards have been used.
Once the cards have been sorted into groups the team may sort large clusters into subgroups for easier management and analysis.<ref>Value: Its Measurement, Design and Management By M. Larry Shillito</ref> Once completed, the affinity diagram may be used to create a [[Ishikawa diagram|cause and effect diagram]].<ref>[http://www.tin.nhs.uk/index.asp?pgid=1129 NHS Improvement network]</ref>
In many cases, the best results tend to be achieved when the activity is completed by a cross-functional team, including key stakeholders. The process requires becoming deeply immersed in the data, which has benefits beyond the tangible deliverables.
==References== {{reflist|2}}
{{Group creativity techniques}} ==External links== {{Commonscat|Affinity diagrams}} * [http://memosort.co/ Memosort - Online tool for collaborative affinity diagramming] * [http://www.discover6sigma.org/d6slab/affinity/ Online AFFINITY tool at Discover 6 Sigma Lab]

{{Other uses|Amalgamation (disambiguation)}} {{Wiktionary|amalgamate|amalgamation}} In the [[business]] world, '''amalgamated''' refers to an organization that has undergone [[amalgamation (business)|amalgamation]]. Amalgamated organizations may use "amalgamated" in their name to signify that it is the amalgamation of its component [[companies]] or [[trade union]]s.
Amalgamated organizations include:
==In North America== * [[Amalgamated Bank of Chicago]], a bank founded in 1923 by the ACWA and now owned by UNITE HERE * [[Amalgamated Sugar Company]] * [[Amalgamated Transit Union]], a United States and Canada based union * [[Amalgamated Advertising]] * [[Dominica Amalgamated Workers' Union]] * [[Amalgamated Workers Union]], a trade union in Trinidad and Tobago
===Now disbanded or further amalgamated=== * [[Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers]], a historical trade union * [[Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America]] * [[Amalgamated Machinery Corporation]], manufacturers of the ''[[Amalgamated (1917 automobile)|Amalgamated]]'' * [[Amalgamated Meat Cutters]], a North American trade union
==In the United Kingdom== * [[Chesham Amalgamations]], a British mergers and acquisitions broking company
===Now disbanded or further amalgamated=== * [[Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union]], a historical British trade union (formerly known as the "Amalgamated Society of Engineers"), now part of Amicus * [[Amalgamated Marine Workers' Union]] * [[Amalgamated Motor Cycles Ltd]] * [[Amalgamated Studios]] * [[Amalgamated Society of Carpenters and Joiners]], a British organisation formed during the 1860s * [[Amalgamated Union of Building Trade Workers]] * [[Anglo-Amalgamated]], a British film production company from the 1930s to the 1970s, responsible for some of the early "Carry On" films * [[Fleetway]] Publications, formerly known as "Amalgamated Press".
==In Asia and Oceania== * [[Amalgamated Society of Engineers (Australia)]] * [[Amalgamated Wireless Australasia Limited]] * [[Central Amalgamated Workers' Union]] * [[Northern Amalgamated Workers' Union]] * [[Southern Amalgamated Workers' Union]]
==In Botswana== * [[Botswana Railways Amalgamated Workers' Union]] * [[National Amalgamated Central, Local & Parastatal Manual Workers' Union]], a Botswana-based organisation
==In fiction== * A large corporation called Consolidated Amalgamated figures in the plots of two films by [[Peter Hyams]]: [[Capricorn One]] (1978) and [[Outland (film)|Outland]] (1981). * [[Amalgamated Fluorodynamics]] is a fictional company in the Half-Life mod [[Science and Industry]]
[[Category:Business terms]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2015}} '''Andres Küng''' (September 13, 1945 – December 10, 2002) was a [[Sweden|Swedish]] journalist, writer, entrepreneur and politician of Estonian origin. He was born in [[Ockelbo]] in [[Gävleborg County]] to a family of refugees from [[Occupation of Baltic Republics|Soviet occupied Estonia]].
==Career==
===Literature=== As he himself noted, Küng "published more than 50 books, most on the [[Baltic States]], thousands of articles and held innumerable lectures on why [[Estonia]], [[Latvia]] and [[Lithuania]] should (and would) become independent again."
===Politics=== Küng was active in both Swedish politics (member of the [[Liberal People's Party (Sweden)|People's Party – Liberals]]) and Baltic émigré activities. He was the chairman of the [[Liberal Students (Sweden)|Liberal Students Club]] of Stockholm between 1966 and 67. Later, he served as the Deputy Board member of the [[Liberal Youth of Sweden|People's Party Youth League]]. During 1970–71, he was the acting Deputy member 1982 of [[Parliament of Sweden|Riksdag]]. Küng also participated in the [[Reformierakond|Estonian Liberal Party]] in exile and several other organisations and campaigns for Baltic struggle for independence.<ref>[http://www.ieg.ee/ak/indexeng.html Andres Küng<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> He was a member of the party board for the Swedish Liberal Party from 1982 until 1991.
==Noted awards== In November 1998, Andres Küng was awarded the Latvian [[Order of the Three Stars]] by the Latvian President [[Guntis Ulmanis]]. In February 1999, he was awarded the Estonian [[Order of the White Star]] by the Estonian President [[Lennart Meri]].<ref>[http://www.ieg.ee/ak/indexo.html Andres Küng] Official biography.</ref>
==Bibliography== *''Sverige och Estland: äntligen goda grannar?'' (Historia i dag) {{ISBN|91-24-16473-9}} *''Bruce Olson: Missionary or colonizer?'', 1981 {{ISBN|0-915684-83-7}} *''Vindens barn: Om medlöperi förr och nu'', 1983 {{ISBN|91-7566-030-X}} *''A dream of freedom: Four decades of national survival versus Russian imperialism in Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania, 1940–1980'' {{ISBN|0-906967-05-8}} *''Kommunismen och Baltikum'', 1999 ("Communism and the Baltic States", see online https://web.archive.org/web/20060504183740/http://www.rel.ee/swe/kommunism_och_baltikum.htm) *''Communism and Crimes against Humanity in the Baltic states'', c 1999, refer http://www.hot.ee/evlliit/okup_2.htm *''Ett liv för Baltikum : journalistiska memoarer.'' – Stockholm : Timbro, 2002. – 351 s. : ill. – {{ISBN|91-7566-530-1}} (Estonian edition: Baltikumile elatud aastad : ajakirjaniku mälestused. – Tallinn, Olion, 2002.) For the complete list, see [http://www.ieg.ee/ak/cvbockereng.html].
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.ieg.ee/ak/ In Memory of Andres Küng's website]

{{Infobox person | image = AndrewFlipFilipowski.jpg | | image_size = 150px | | name = Andrew J. "Flip" Filipowski | caption = | birth_date = 1950 | birth_place = [[Chicago, IL]] | death_date = | death_place = | other_names = | known_for = | occupation = Technology Entrepreneur }}
'''Andrew J. "Flip" Filipowski''' is a [[Poland|Polish]] American technology entrepreneur born in 1950 in [[Chicago, IL|Chicago]]. He is currently the Executive Chairman and CEO of SilkRoad Equity, a private investment firm, and founded [[Platinum Technology|Platinum technology]] in 1987. He is also currently the Co-CEO of [http://www.flur.ee Fluree PBC], a blockchain database technology company. He also founded and is the Chairman of VeriBlock a leading technology company that provides Bitcoin security to the world's blockchain. He founded or co-founded [[Blue Rhino|Blue Rhino Corporation]], Primo Water, SilkRoad technology Inc., DBMS Inc., the [[House of Blues]], SolidSpace Inc., Onramp Branding, MissionMode, Unocoin and InterAct 911.<ref>[http://www.interact911.com/andrew-flip-filipowski-biography/ InterAct - Andrew Filipowski Biography] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130523221652/http://www.interact911.com/andrew-flip-filipowski-biography/ |date=May 23, 2013 }}</ref> Platinum technology was sold to [[Computer Associates]] in 1999 for $4 billion, a record at the time for a software company.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.crn.com/it-channel/18803143 |title=CA To Buy Platinum For $3.5 Billion |publisher=CRN |accessdate=2007-08-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927232050/http://www.crn.com/it-channel/18803143 |archivedate=2007-09-27 }}</ref> Filipowski's personal proceeds from the deal were $290 million.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/08/01/business/private-sector-a-maverick-has-plans-for-chicago.html?pagewanted=all|title= PRIVATE SECTOR; A Maverick Has Plans for Chicago|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=2008-06-16 | first=David | last=Barboza | date=1999-08-01}}</ref>
Filipowski founded or served in an executive capacity in a number of companies including [[Divine (corporation)|divine, inc.]], DBMS, Inc. and [[Cullinet]] Corp; he also served in various managerial and technical positions with A.B. Dick, [[Motorola]] and [[Time, Inc]]. Throughout the course of his career, Filipowski, along with his management team, has acquired and integrated nearly 200 public and private companies.
Filipowski was the 1998 recipient of the [[Anti-Defamation League]]'s Torch of Liberty Award, first for the [[Silicon Prairie]] (Chicago), for his support in fighting hate on the Internet.
In 2000, he was named one of the 100 most influential individuals in the technology field in [[Upside (magazine)|''Upside'' magazine]]’s 2000 Upside Elite 100 list.
Flip is a futurist and renowned speaker on such topics as Bitcoin, Crypto Assets, Blockchain, FinTech, History of Money, Energy, Disruption, Venture Capital, Entrepreneurship, Digital Autonomous Organizations, and Organizational Structures. Flip is a resource for YPO/WPO and has recently keynoted at Blockchain events in Kenya, Kazakhstan, Toronto and at industry events such as the Blockchain Cruise Asia 2018, North America Bitcoin Conference, Blockchain Nation among others

{{Infobox company | name = Association of Old Crows | logo = Association of Old Crows (logo).png | type = [[Non-profit]] | foundation = 1964 | location = {{nowrap| [[Alexandria, Virginia]], [[United States]]}} | area_served = Worldwide | industry = [[Electronic Warfare]], [[Information Operations]], [[Cyberwarfare]] | homepage = {{URL|http://www.crows.org/}} }} The '''Association of Old Crows''' is an international professional organization specializing in [[electronic warfare]], tactical information operations, and associated disciplines headquartered in [[Alexandria, Virginia]]. This nonprofit organization's mission is to "advocate the need for a strong defense capability emphasizing electronic warfare and information operations to government, industry, academia, and the public."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crows.org/about/mission-a-history.html|title=Mission & History – Uncategorized – About|author=Bridgette Anderson|publisher=|accessdate=8 December 2015}}</ref>
The name "Old Crows" emerged from the first use of electronic warfare in [[World War II]] to disrupt [[Axis powers|Axis]] communications and radars. [[Allies of World War II|Allied]] equipment and operators were known by the code name "Raven". Common jargon changed the name to "Crows" and those engaged in the profession became known as "Old Crows".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.buffalostate.edu/physics/x757.xml |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-08-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928144251/http://www.buffalostate.edu/physics/x757.xml |archivedate=2011-09-28 |df= }}</ref>
The organization draws expertise and information from its members, a pool of thousands of individuals including technology specialists and actual military personnel, and is involved in advancing electronic warfare and [[Intelligence assessment|information-gathering]] techniques, disseminating information on these topics, and supporting the education of personnel in related scientific matters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crows.org/about/about-aoc.html|title=About AOC – Uncategorized – About|author=Bridgette Anderson|publisher=|accessdate=8 December 2015}}</ref>
It publishes the ''[[Journal of Electronic Defense]],'' a journal covering international developments in the fields of electronic warfare, [[signals intelligence]], [[electronic intelligence]] and [[communications intelligence]].
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.crows.org/ Official site] * [https://www.crows.org/page/chapters Association of Old Crows - List of Chapters] * [http://www.oldcrows.org.au/ Association of Old Crows Australian Chapter]

[[CAC Mid 60|CAC Mid 60 Component]] | foundation = {{Start date and age|1822}} | location = | location_city = [[Puteaux]] | location_country = [[France]] | key_people = [[Vincent Bolloré]]
([[President (corporate title)|President]] & [[Chief executive officer|CEO]])
[[Yannick Bolloré]]
(Vice-Chairman)
Thierry Marraud ([[Chief financial officer|CFO]]) | industry = [[Transport]] | products = [[Logistics]], [[cargo]], [[paper]], [[Car|automobile]]s | revenue = [[Euro|€]]10 billion (2012) | operating_income = €174 million (2009) | net_income = €120 million (2009) | num_employees = 33,000 (2009) | parent = Bolloré Investissements S.A (92.2%) | subsid = [[Havas|Havas Group]] (60%) | homepage = {{URL|http://www.bollore.com}} | footnotes = }} '''Bolloré''' is a French transportation company headquartered in [[Puteaux]], on the western outskirts of [[Paris]], [[France]]. The company, a paper–energy–plantations–logistics conglomerate, employs 28,000 people around the world. In 2004, the group ranked amongst the top 200 European companies. Whilst the company is listed on the [[Euronext]] exchange in [[Paris]], the Bolloré family retains majority control of the company through a complex and indirect holding structure. The company is led by [[Vincent Bolloré]]. ==History== The firm was founded in 1822, in [[Ergué-Gabéric]], near [[Quimper, Finistère|Quimper]], [[Brittany]] by Nicolas Le Marié (1797-1870), as a paper manufacturer named ''papeteries d'Odet''. Beginning in 1863, it was directed by Jean-René Bolloré (1818–1881), a nephew by marriage who had obtained a medical doctorate in 1863. The firm remained owned by the Bolloré family. [[Gwenn-Aël Bolloré]] was Vice-President of the [[Papeteries Bolloré]] from 1952 to 1974. In late 2004 the Bolloré group began taking an interest in the advertising sector, and started building a stake in [[Havas]], becoming its single largest share-holder. In a [[boardroom coup]] Alain de Pouzilhac was deposed as President and [[CEO]] on July 12, 2005. The Bolloré stake in Havas stood at 26%, and the group had 3 seats on the Havas board as of June 2006. Vincent Bolloré's son [[Yannick Bolloré]] is now Havas' Chairman and CEO after the stepping down of its previous CEO in January 2014. In 2005 Bolloré expanded its media interests by launching the television station [[Direct 8]]. The firm also began buying shares of the British [[media planning|media planning and buying]] group [[Aegis Group plc|Aegis]]. Bolloré sold its 26% stake to [[Dentsu]] in 2012.{{cite web | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/dentsu-aegis-bollore-idUSWEA645620120712| title = Bollore agrees to sell Aegis stake to Dentsu |date = 2012-07-02 | publisher = Reuters }} From June 6, 2006 to December 22, 2010,{{cite web|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/medias/2012/01/10/04002-20120110ARTFIG00390-la-pub-a-progresse-de-44-dans-la-presse-en-2011.php |title=La pub a progressé de 4,4 % dans la presse en 2011 |publisher=lefigaro.fr |date= |accessdate= }} Bolloré launched a free evening newspaper [[Direct Soir]]. Lack of readers and advertising revenues made the group focus on its other free newspaper, "Direct Matin", launched in February 2007.{{cite web|url=http://www.strategies.fr/etudes-tendances/dossiers/208421/207838W/presse-gratuite.html |title=Dossier presse gratuite |publisher=strategies.fr |date= |accessdate= }} On February 17, 2009, Bolloré held talks with Bolivian President [[Evo Morales]] about the use of its [[lithium]] reserves for [[electric vehicle]] batteries.{{cite web|url=http://www.rfi.fr/actuen/articles/110/article_2926.asp |title=RFI - Be partners not predators, Morales warns French firms on Paris visit |publisher=Rfi.fr |date= |accessdate=2012-06-14}} Bolloré manufactures the [[Bolloré Bluecar]], a small electric car, initially produced to showcase the company's range of electric power cells. The Bluecar was introduced in December 2011 as part of the [[Autolib']] [[carsharing]] service in Paris.{{cite web|url=http://www.sustainableguernsey.info/blog/2011/12/autolib-electric-car-sharing-service-launches-in-paris-france/|title=Autolib’ electric car sharing service launches in Paris, France|author=Richard Lord |publisher=Sustainable Guernsey|date=2011-12-05|accessdate=2011-12-17}} Bluecar deliveries to retail customers began in March 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.avem.fr/news?id=2995|title=Bolloré Bluecar – 1000 immatriculations pour Autolib’ et début des livraisons pour les particuliers|trans-title=Bolloré Bluecar– 1000 cars registered for Autolib’ and deliveries for individuals begin|language=French|author=Michaël Torregrossa|publisher=AVEM|date=2012-03-07|accessdate=2012-03-21}} In 2014 Bollore increased its stake in Havas from 36 percent to around 83 percent through a public exchange offer of new Bollore shares for Havas stock. The company said at the time it would like to hold onto a stake well in excess of 50 percent. In March 2015, Bollore sold a 22.5 percent stake in the media group for a price of around €600 million. {{cite press release | publisher=Reuters| date=26 March 2015| title=Bollore sells 22.5 percent Havas stake for $662 million | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/03/26/us-havas-bollore-stake-idUSKBN0ML22F20150326}} The next month, in April 2015, Bollore raised its stake in [[Vivendi]] from 10.2 percent to 12.01 percent at a total cost of €568 million.{{cite press release | publisher=Reuters| date=2 April 2015| title= Bollore raises Vivendi stake again as AGM battle looms | url= https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/04/02/us-bollore-vivendi-idUSKBN0MT0OO20150402}} As of 2016, it owns 20% of Vivendi (30% voting power), 60% of Havas and 9% of [[Gaumont Film Company|Gaumont]]{{cite web|url=http://www.bollore.com/en-us/activities/portfolio-of-shareholdings|title=Portfolio of shareholdings - Bolloré|website=www.bollore.com}}{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2016/digital/global/vincent-bollore-ups-stake-voting-rights-in-vivendi-1201885211/|title=Vincent Bolloré Ups Stake, Voting Rights in Vivendi|first=Elsa|last=Keslassy|date=11 October 2016|publisher=}} ==Operations== [[Image:Bolloré Énergie.JPG|thumb|Bolloré Énergie]] The Group's principal activities are as follows: * Transport & Logistics: freight forwarding by sea, land and air, port, handling and shipping services, operation of shipping lines; * Plastic Film & Special Papers''': polypropylene film for capacitors and packaging, special papers and cigarette paper packs; * Energy Distribution: distribution of petroleum and coal products; * Special Terminals: design, production, integration and distribution of intelligent systems and terminals for access control; * Plantations : rubber and palm oil production in Africa and Asia * Other Interests ': real estate and banking sectors, * Media & Advertising : owns 60% of the media and communications company Havas owns stake in French media giant Vivendi * Telecommunication: owns 90% of [[Bolloré telecom]], a French [[WiMAX]] operator == Electric vehicles == === AutoLib === There are plans to integrate payment for the bike and car hire schemes with the ticketing systems for traditional modes of public transport. Two electric vehicle manufacturers are said to be in the frame to supply the cars: the [[Dassault Group]] and Bolloré. The former has a vehicle called the [[Cleanova]], which employs the body of the Renault Kangoo van, while Bolloré’s Bluecar has been developed with Italian styling house [[Pininfarina]] and is due to go on sale commercially in 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.bikeradar.com/news/article/move-over-velib-autolib-is-on-its-way-17274 |title=Move Over Velib, Autolib Is On Its Way |publisher=BikeRadar |date=2008-06-30 |accessdate=2012-06-14}}{{update after|2009}} [[File:Autolib' Station, Paris, Boulevard Diderot 02.jpg|thumb|Bolloré Bluecar charging at Autolib' Station on boulevard Diderot, Paris]] === Pininfarina B0 === [[Pininfarina]] introduced its own electric vehicle concept, the [[Pininfarina B0]] ("B Zero"). The four-seat hatchback features a solid-state lithium-polymer battery, supercapacitors, and a roof- integrated solar panel to achieve a range of 153 miles. Developed in partnership with the Bolloré Group, the vehicle was slated for limited production in 2009.{{cite web|url=http://apps1.eere.energy.gov/news/enn.cfm#id_12040 |title=EERE News: EERE Network News |publisher=Apps1.eere.energy.gov |date= |accessdate=2012-06-14}}[http://www.pininfarina.com/index/storiaModelli/B0.html ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081005071729/http://www.pininfarina.com/index/storiaModelli/B0.html |date=October 5, 2008 }}{{update after|2009}} ===Bluecar=== {{See also|Bolloré Bluecar|Autolib'}} Bolloré manufactures the [[Bolloré Bluecar]], a small electric car, initially produce to showcase the company's range of electric power cells. The Bluecar was introduced in December 2011, as part of the [[Autolib']] [[carsharing]] service in Paris. Bluecar deliveries to retail customers began in March 2012. {{As of|2017|post=,|since=y}} Bolloré's Bluecar is also used in the Bluecity London car sharing scheme.{{cite web|last1=Smith|first1=Rebecca|title=Bluecity is expanding its electric car sharing service across London after successful Hammersmith and Fulham pilot|url=http://www.cityam.com/266620/bluecity-expanding-its-electric-car-sharing-service-across|website=City A.M.|date=2017-06-14|accessdate=23 August 2017}} ===Bluebus=== Bolloré [[Bluebus]] has capacity for 22 passengers. Two copies of this electric vehicle transportation arrived mid-April 2015 to [[Mulhouse]], [[Haut-Rhin]].{{cite web|url=http://www.avem.fr/actualite-deux-bluebus-debarquent-a-mulhouse-5689.html|title=Deux Bluebus débarquent à Mulhouse|first=Association|last=AVEM|publisher=}} ===Solar vehicles=== [[Hanergy]] has teamed with Bollore Group to build [[solar electric vehicle]]s . ==See also== * [[Bolloré Logistics]] * [[Hanergy]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} == External links == * [http://www.bollore.com Bolloré Group] * [http://www.bollore-logistics.com Bolloré Logistics] * [http://www.bollore-africa-logistics.com Bolloré Africa Logistics] {{automotive industry in France}} {{CAC Mid 60}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bollore}} [[Category:Conglomerate companies of France]] [[Category:Motor vehicle manufacturers of France]] [[Category:French business families]] [[Category:Companies established in 1822]] [[Category:Multinational companies headquartered in France]] [[Category:1822 establishments in France]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2015}} {{Use British English|date=February 2015}} {{refimprove|date=October 2011}} {{Infobox UK place |official_name= Cardiff City Centre |welsh_name= Canol y Ddinas, Caerdydd |static_image_name=The Hayes South in Cardiff.JPG |static_image_caption=The Hayes, Cardiff with Cardiff Central Library (right) |country= Wales |constituency_welsh_assembly= [[Cardiff Central (Assembly constituency)|Cardiff Central]] |coordinates = {{coord|51.48|-3.17|display=inline,title}} |unitary_wales= [[Cardiff]] |lieutenancy_wales= [[Cardiff]] |constituency_westminster= [[Cardiff Central (UK Parliament constituency)|Cardiff Central]] |post_town= CARDIFF |postcode_district = CF10; CF11; CF24 |postcode_area= CF |dial_code= 029 }}
[[File:Cardiff city centre skyscrapers.JPG|thumb|upright|right|[[Stadium House, Cardiff|Stadium House]] (left) and South Gate House (right), in the west of the city centre]]
'''Cardiff city centre''' ({{lang-cy|Canol Dinas Caerdydd}}) is the [[city centre]] and [[central business district]] of [[Cardiff]], [[Wales]]. The area is tightly bound by the [[River Taff]] to the west, the Civic Centre to the north and railway lines and two railway stations – [[Cardiff Central railway station|Central]] and [[Cardiff Queen Street|Queen Street]] – to the south and east respectively. Cardiff became a city in 1905.
The city centre in Cardiff consists of principal shopping streets: Queen Street, St. Mary's Street and the Hayes, as well as large [[shopping centre]]s, and [[List of shopping arcades in Cardiff|numerous arcades]] and lanes that house some smaller, specialized shops and boutiques.
The city centre has undergone a number of redevelopment projects, including [[St. David's Centre#St. David's 2|St. David's 2]],<ref>{{cite web | url = http://stdavidscardiff.com/About-us/Development | title = Development – {{font|size=90%| text = Project overview}} | year = 2013 | accessdate = {{date| 9 mar 2013}} }}</ref> which extended the shopping district southwards, creating 100 new stores and a flagship [[John Lewis (department store)|John Lewis]], the only branch in Wales and the largest outside [[London]]. Compared to nearby cities, the new St David's Centre has more retail space than the whole of [[Newport, Wales|Newport]] or [[Swansea]].{{citation needed|date=October 2011}}
In 2008–9, the annual [[wikt:footfall|footfall]] of shoppers was 55 million, and is expected to have risen to 66 million by 2009–10.{{update needed|date=October 2013}}<ref>{{cite news | title = Shoppers numbers set to soar in Cardiff | url = http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/cardiff-news/2009/06/03/shoppers-numbers-set-to-soar-in-cardiff-91466-23774599/ | last = Alford | first = Abby | accessdate = {{date| 9 mar 2013}} | publisher = Welsh Media Ltd | date = {{date| 3 jun 2009}} | work = South Wales Echo }}</ref> Cardiff is the sixth most successful shopping destination in the [[United Kingdom]] – behind London, Glasgow, Birmingham, Manchester and Liverpool.<ref>{{cite news | title = Capital investment pushes Cardiff up retail rankings | url = http://www.walesonline.co.uk/business-in-wales/business-news/2009/11/25/capital-investment-pushes-cardiff-up-retail-rankings-91466-25245234/ | last = Alford | first = Abby | accessdate = {{date| 9 mar 2013}} | publisher = Welsh Media Ltd | date = {{date| 25 nov 2009}} | work = Western Mail }}</ref>
==History==
{{main|History of Cardiff}} [[Image:John Speed's map of Cardiff 1610.jpg|thumb|left|[[John Speed]]'s 1610 map of Cardiff]] Cardiff was granted city status by [[Edward VII]] in 1905.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/27849/pages/7248 | title = Grant of Letters Patent | work = London Gazette | issue = Issue 27849 | pages = 7248–7249 | date = {{date|October 31, 1905}} | accessdate = {{date| 9 mar 2013}} }}</ref>
In the 1960s, planners described Cardiff city centre as "worn out, inconvenient, drab and dangerous". The centre had escaped the extensive wartime bomb damage inflicted on other cities, so little redevelopment took place in the 1950s and 1960s. The Buchanan Plan of 1964 envisaged a highly ambitious extended city centre, crossed with urban motorways. The council scrapped the proposed motorway network and focused on the small commercial core of the city; its proposed redevelopment scheme, in partnership with a private developer, would have seen almost all of the city centre (except St Mary Street and Working Street) demolished, replaced by [[Modern architecture|modernist]] office towers of up to 21 storeys and pedestrianised decks linking [[multi-storey car park|multi{{nbhyph}}storey car park]]s to covered shopping malls.<ref name="Hooper">{{cite book | editor = Hooper, A | editor2 = Punter, J | title = Capital Cardiff 1975–2020: Regeneration, Competitiveness and the Urban Environment | location = Cardiff | publisher = [[University of Wales Press]] | isbn = 9780708320631 | year = 2006 }}</ref>
By the time the legal agreement to implement 'Centreplan 70' was signed, the 1973 property crash had made it unviable. However, one legacy of the scheme was the future segregation of office and retail development, with the west end of Newport Road as the principal office area with secondary concentrations on Churchill Way, Greyfriars Road and Westgate Street.<ref name="Hooper"/>
Development in the 1970s and 80s was more piecemeal than envisaged in Centreplan, with the building of the St. David's Centre and St David's Hall, new multi{{nbhyph}}storey car parks, and the grant{{nbhyph}}supported construction of the 14{{nbhyph}}storey Holiday Inn (now the Marriott) and World Trade Centre (now the Cardiff International Arena), which gave a fillip to the city's conference and exhibition business. In the mid–1980s developers returned to Queen Street, creating three medium{{nbhyph}}sized malls, helping it to become one of the best performing shopping streets in the country in terms of footfall and rental levels.<ref name="Hooper"/>
In the 1990s the Mill Lane cafe quarter was developed in partnership with the [[Welsh Development Agency]], a pedestrian forecourt was created for the refurbished Central railway station, a new walkway was constructed alongside the Taff and the [[Millennium Stadium]] was built on the site of the [[Cardiff_Arms_Park#National_Stadium|National Stadium]] and [[Wales Empire Pool|Empire Pool]]. The latter became, according to official publicists, one of the icons of Cardiff's new image.<ref name="Hooper"/>
==Castle Quarter==
The [[Castle Quarter]] includes some of [[List of shopping arcades in Cardiff|Cardiff's Victorian and Edwardian arcades]]: Castle Arcade, High Street Arcade and Duke Street Arcade, and principal shopping streets: [[St. Mary Street/High Street|St Mary Street, High Street]], Castle Street and Duke Street.
Development of the area began in February 2010 and is expected to be completed by July 2011. [[Cardiff Council]] says that work to create the Castle Quarter as a pedestrian friendly environment for High Street and St Mary Street is designed to enhance the city centre.<ref>{{cite web | title = Cardiff shops seek compensation for roadworks | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-11647951 | work = BBC News Wales | publisher = BBC | date = {{date| 29 oct 2010}} | accessdate = {{date| 9 mar 2013}} }}</ref>
===Castle Street/Duke Street/Kingsway===
[[File:Duke Street Arcade Cardiff.JPG|thumb|right|upright|Duke Street Arcade]] '''Castle Street''' follows on from Cowbridge Road East from [[Canton, Cardiff|Canton]] and begins after Cardiff Bridge, over the [[River Taff]]. It becomes '''Duke Street''' after the junction with High Street before turning north and becoming '''Kingsway''', leading to [[Cathays Park|Cardiff Civic Centre]]. From west to east, streets that begin from the southern side of this stretch are Westgate Street, Womanby Street, High Street (St Marys Street), St Johns Street (The Hayes), Queen Street and Greyfriars Road. [[Cardiff Castle]] and [[Bute Park]] dominate the northern side of the street. On the southern side are pubs, bars, retail and hotel units. Castle Arcade and Duke Street Arcades begin from this stretch.
===St. Mary Street and High Street===
{{main|St. Mary Street/High Street}} [[Image:St. Mary Street, Cardiff.jpg|thumb|left|St. Mary Street south end]] [[File:Womanby Street - Cardiff - geograph.org.uk - 1575663.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Womanby Street looking south]] '''St. Mary Street''' ({{lang-cy|Heol Eglwys Fair}}) and '''High Street''' ({{lang-cy|Heol Fawr}}). The former street is named after the 11th century church of St. Mary, the largest in Cardiff until it was destroyed by the [[Bristol Channel floods, 1607|Bristol Channel floods]] of 1607. Today the stretch of road is the home of a number of [[bar (establishment)|bar]]s, [[night club]]s and [[restaurant]]s, as well as branches of many major [[bank]]s. Also fronting onto the street is [[Howells (department store)|Howells]] department store, which stretches from just after [[Cardiff Central Market]] to the corner of Wharton Street. From August 2007 the street was closed to private vehicles, leaving only buses, cycles and taxis allowed to access the whole street.{{citation needed|date=October 2011}} The street is usually closed to all traffic every Friday and Saturday night to allow the efflux from [[night club]]s and [[pub]]s located in that part of the street to clear. It is also closed when major events take place such as at the [[Millennium Stadium]].<ref>{{cite web | title = City Centre Improvements | url = http://www.cardiff.gov.uk/content.asp?nav=2870%2C4048%2C4188%2C5137&parent_directory_id=2865&id=5317 | work = Cardiff Transport Strategy | publisher = Cardiff Council / Cyngor Caerdydd | date = {{date|22 dec 2011}} | accessdate = {{date| 9 mar 2013}} }}</ref> The Prince Of Wales is a prominent [[Wetherspoons|J D Wetherspoon]] establishment at the junction with Wood Street, which leads to Central Station. At the northern end of the street is Castle Street and [[Cardiff Castle]]. To the south is Callaghan Square.
===Womanby Street===
Womanby Street is one of Cardiff's oldest streets. It is known for its small, independent live music venues and is home to [[Clwb Ifor Bach]]. It is accessed from Castle Street, between Westgate Street and High Street.
==Queen Street and vicinity==
[[File:Summer on Queen Street - Cardiff - geograph.org.uk - 1363923.jpg|thumb|left|Queen Street]] '''Queen Street''' ({{lang-cy|Heol y Frenhines}}) is the main thoroughfare in the city, now wholly pedestrianised. Most of Queen Street, from the castle moat to Dumfries Place, used to be called '''Crockherbtown''' (Crockherbtown Lane can still be found off Park Place),<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.keytothecity.co.uk/dayout.htm#shops | title = City Centre Shopping – Queen Street | date = | accessdate = {{date|9 mar 2013}} }}</ref> but the street was renamed in honour of [[Queen Victoria]] in 1886.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.peterfinch.co.uk/charles.htm | title = Charles Street | work = Real Cardiff | accessdate = {{date|9 mar 2013}} }}</ref> Queen Street was pedestrianised in 1974 and is served by [[Cardiff Queen Street railway station]] on Station Terrace. It meets Dumfries Place/Newport Road at its eastern end, Duke Street/Castle Street at its western, and Park Place approximately halfway along. Further down Park Place is the [[New Theatre (Cardiff)|New Theatre]], a local landmark is Principality House, head office of the [[Principality Building Society]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.principality.co.uk/en/About-Us/About-Principality.aspx | title = Principality Building Society | date = | accessdate = {{date|9 mar 2013}} }}</ref> To the north running parallel is Greyfriars Road, referring to the site of an old monastery, a traditional office location that has recently seen conversion to bars, apartments and hotels as offices move to the new business parks on the edge of the city, or to the better connected southern end of the city centre.
==Cathays Park (Civic Centre)== {{main|Cathays Park}}
[[File:Cathays Park, Cardiff.png|thumb|Cathays Park]] Cathays Park is the [[civic centre]] of Cardiff. The [[Edwardian]] architecture of [[Cardiff City Hall]], [[National Museum Cardiff|National Museum and Gallery of Wales]], [[Cardiff University]], [[Cardiff Crown Court]], and the administrative headquarters of the [[Welsh Government]] dominate the area. Behind the City Hall is the [[Welsh National War Memorial]]. [[Bute Park]] also dominates the northwest of the area, running behind [[Cardiff Castle]] along the River Taff southward to Westgate Street and northward to [[Gabalfa]]. Cardiff's Winter Wonderland [[ice rink]] and fairground returns to the front lawn of the City Hall every winter.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cardiff.gov.uk/content.asp?nav=2868%2C2964%2C4981&parent_directory_id=2865 |title=Cardiff's Winter Wonderland |publisher=Cardiff City Council |accessdate={{date| 9 mar 2013}} |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120805204441/http://www.cardiff.gov.uk/content.asp?nav=2868%2C2964%2C4981&parent_directory_id=2865 |archivedate=5 August 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref>
Boulevard de [[Nantes]] and [[Stuttgart]]er Strasse, named after Cardiff's twin cities, run through the southern end and act as a northern bypass of parallel Queen Street for the A4161. To the west, it is connected to Kingsway (leading to Castle Street and St Mary Street), and Dumfries Place/ Newport Road to the east. Park Place runs north to south through the area, linking it to the A470 in the north and Queen Street in the south
==Eastern city centre==
===Dumfries Place/Newport Road===
[[File:Queen Street junction with Dumfries Place.JPG|thumb|left|The junction of Newport Road, Queen Street and Dumfries Place]] '''Dumfries Place''' is named after the [[Earl of Dumfries]], a courtesy title given to the [[Marquis of Bute]]'s eldest son.
[[Newport Road]], the major road leading east from Queen Street towards the neighbouring city of [[Newport, Wales|Newport]], has been one of the prime office locations of central Cardiff since the 1960s. Some of the original buildings have been converted from office use to residential (e.g. The Aspect, Admiral House<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.skyscrapernews.com/buildings.php?id=967 | title = Admiral House {{font|size=90%|text = Also known as Forty Newport Road}} | date = {{date|22 dec 2008}} | accessdate = {{date| 9 mar 2013}} }}</ref> or hotel use including the [[Holland House, Cardiff|Mercure Holland House]]. Occupancy of the remaining commercial property has increased, reflecting a shortage of office space in the city and there is now little scope for further conversion. Newport Road is also home to several buildings owned by [[Cardiff University]], and Shand House, occupied by [[Cardiff Institute for the Blind]].
Newport Road is also the site for the [[Cardiff Royal Infirmary]], now providing long term care and rehabilitation. The hospital once housed 500 beds and provided the main A&E service for Cardiff before the [[University Hospital of Wales]] took over these functions.
[[File:The big squeeze^ - geograph.org.uk - 1186370.jpg|thumb|right|The eastern side of Churchill Way]]
===Churchill Way===
'''Churchill Way''' runs parallel to the west of Station Terrace (Cardiff Queen Street station) and joins Queen Street in the north and Bute Terrace in the south. The [[Capitol Centre]] is on the corner with Queen Street. Further along this road are office and modern apartment developments. The Cardiff office of the [[Driving Standards Agency]], former [[Centrica|British Gas]] offices in [[Helmont House]] (now a [[Premier Inn]]), and an [[Hotel Ibis|Ibis]] Hotel are located on this street. The Cardiff office of the DSA subsequently closed.<ref>{{cite web | title = The closure of the Driving Standards Agency office in Cardiff | url = https://www.gov.uk/government/speeches/the-closure-of-the-driving-standards-agency-office-in-cardiff | publisher = [[Department for Transport]] | date = {{date|18 jan 2011}} | accessdate = {{date| 9 mar 2013}} }}</ref> <ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.ibis.com/gb/hotel-2936-ibis-cardiff/index.shtml | title = Hotel Ibis Cardiff | date = | publisher = Accor Hotels | website = www.accorhotels.com | accessdate = {{date| 9 mar 2013}} }}</ref>
[http://www.cardiffmasonichall.co.uk/ Cardiff Masonic Hall] occupies a major site on the corner of Guildford Street, adjacent to Churchill Way.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.cardiffmasonichall.co.uk/ | title = Cardiff Masonic Hall | date = | accessdate = {{date| 9 mar 2013}} }}</ref>
==Southwestern city centre==
===Wood Street=== [[File:Wood Street, Cardiff.jpg|thumb|Wood Street]] '''Wood Street''' is the main access point for [[Cardiff Central railway station|Cardiff Central railway]] and [[Cardiff Central bus station|Central bus]] stations, with the latter undergoing reconstruction since early 2008. The street also has bus stands running along the length of the street as well. Travelling westwards along this street are the [[Millennium Stadium]], Millennium Plaza (with bars, night clubs, comedy clubs and a [[Vue Cinemas|Vue cinema]]), [[Stadium House]], ''Media Wales'' (offices of the [[South Wales Echo]] and [[Western Mail (Wales)|Western Mail]]) and Southgate House, (which houses among other organisations the Cardiff offices for the Armed Forces).
===Central Square=== {{main|Central Square, Cardiff}} '''Central Square''' is a large public space between Wood Street and Cardiff Central railway station. It includes Cardiff bus station. In 2012 plans were announced to redevelop the square and rename it 'Capital Square'.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/local-news/cardiff/2012/01/30/major-firms-eye-up-new-hqs-on-cardiff-bus-station-site-91466-30224710/ | title = Major firms eye up new HQs on Cardiff bus station site | last = Law | first = Peter | accessdate = {{date| 9 mar 2013}} | publisher = Welsh Media Ltd | date = {{date|30 jan 2012}} | work = South Wales Echo }}</ref>
===Westgate Street=== [[File:Westgate_Street_(south)_Cardiff.JPG|thumb|right|upright|The southern end of Westgate Street towards the perpendicular Wood Street]]
'''Westgate Street''' runs parallel just west of St Marys Street for about half of the latter's length, linked by several alleys and lanes. Linking Castle Street and Wood Street, [[Cardiff Arms Park]] and the [[Millennium Stadium]] dominate its western side, whereas pubs and bars and hotels dominate its eastern side, with the [[Angel Hotel, Cardiff|Angel Hotel]] at the north end and the [[Royal Hotel, Cardiff|Royal Hotel]] to the south.
==The Hayes== {{main|The Hayes}} [[Image:Cardiff arcade.jpg|left|thumb|upright|Morgan Arcade]] [[File:Caroline Street Cardiff.JPG|thumb|left|upright|Caroline Street looking south]] The Hayes ({{lang-cy|Yr Ais}}) is where the [[department store]] [[Howells (department store)|Howells]], Bwyty Hayes Island Snack Bar, [[Spillers Records]], [[St David's Hall]], and elegant [[Victorian architecture|Victorian]] [[Arcade (architecture)|arcade]]s are found. At the northern end is Cardiff's Grade II* listed [[Old Library, Cardiff|Old Library building]] (location of the [[Cardiff Story]] people's museum).
The Hayes used to be home to [[David Morgan (department store)|David Morgan department store]], an historic local landmark that dominated the shop fronts on the western side of The Hayes. Since its closure in 2005, the Grade I{{nbhyph}}listed David Morgan Buildings have been subdivided into several retail units, and the upper floors converted into 56 luxury apartments. The exterior of the building received a comprehensive refurbishment, with the street clock being reinstated and the façade being restored to its original design, following many alterations since its construction in the late 1800s.
The eastern side of the Hayes is fronted by the new [[St. David's Centre#St. David's|St. Davids 2]] shopping centre. Prior to this it was home to Oxford Arcade, a post war construction that dated quickly and was underused given its central location.
[[File:Alliance Cardiff.jpg|thumb|right|upright|[[Alliance (sculpture)|Alliance]] in front of Cardiff Central Library]] The southern end features the [[John Lewis (department store)|John Lewis department store]] and the new [[Cardiff Central Library]], which opened in March 2009. The previous Central Library closed in 2006 to make way for the construction of the St. David's 2 shopping centre and was located a few hundred yards north-east on Bridge Street.
As part of the St Davids 2 development, the Hayes was pedestrianised and repaved. A new public square was created at its southern end with a large, interactive public artwork as its centrepiece called [[Alliance (sculpture)|Alliance]], a {{convert|25|m|ft|0}} high sculpture consisting of a large stainless steel and enamelled metal ring and an arrow column, which was initially meant to feature lights that would rise and fall with the tide.
===Caroline Street=== {{main|Caroline Street (Cardiff)}} Caroline Street is a pedestrianised link between St Mary Street and The Hayes. The street has been a host to all kinds of stores but has seen a surge in chip and kebab shops, and as such is commonly known as ''Chip Lane'' or ''Chip Alley''. Around 2003, the north side of the street was redeveloped after the demolition of the old [[S A Brain|Brains]] Brewery. In its place were luxury flats encircling the [[Old Brewery Quarter]], where new shops, bars and restaurants were erected. The pavement on the street was re{{nbhyph}}tiled as part of this development.
==Southeastern city centre==
===Callaghan Square=== {{main|Callaghan Square}}
This development, built in 1999, extends the central business district south of the mainline railway. Eventually the main development will include approximately 850,000 square feet (77,000 m²) of office space and other uses, of which approximately 350,000 square feet (33,000 m²) is complete (with the largest occupiers being Eversheds and British Gas). Further phases are unlikely to be built on a speculative basis. The initial masterplan suggest that the final phase, yet to be commenced, will also include hotel and residential use. Nearby offices on Tresillian Way (housing The AA, and Lloyds TSB Black Horse finance amongst others) plus further potential developments have turned the area relatively quickly into one of the largest office locations in Central Cardiff. Within a few years total office space in the area will exceed 1 million square feet (90,000 m²).{{citation needed|date=April 2012}}
[[File:Atrium, Cardiff.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Atrium]]
===Custom House Street/Bute Terrace/Adam Street===
These two roads have traditionally formed the southern and southeastern boundaries of the [[central business district]] of Cardiff, and in the 2000s have seen a great deal of new development. Recent developments such as the 23{{nbhyph}}storey [[Altolusso]] apartment complex, and the Big Sleep Hotel were set to be joined by (from west to east), a new 11{{nbhyph}}storey office building (on the site of the 120-year-old Central Hotel – destroyed by fire in early 2003;<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/tm_method=full&objectid=13213967&siteid=50082-name_page.html | title = Central Hotel to get new lease of life | last = Day | first = Louise | accessdate = {{date| 9 mar 2013}} | publisher = Welsh Media Ltd | date = {{date|24 jul 2003}} | work = South Wales Echo }}</ref> the [[Meridian Gate, Cardiff|Meridian Gate]] development (consisting of an 11{{nbhyph}}storey apartment block and a 21{{nbhyph}}storey Radisson SAS Hotel); a new John Lewis department store as part of the St. David's 2 shopping expansion; Harlech Court (consisting of apartments and a rooftop restaurant); the [[University of South Wales]]'s [[Atrium (Cardiff)|ATRiuM]] campus (which opened in 2007) along with the 21{{nbhyph}}storey [[Tŷ Pont Haearn]] student halls; and 3 further residential towers (of up to 13 storeys) with lower floor retail and commercial use.
==Access==
From the north, North Road (A470) meets the city centre at the junction with Castle Street and Boulevard de Nantes, with the latter route forming a northern and eastern by{{nbhyph}}pass, meeting Newport Road (A4161) and then Callaghan Square, just south of the city centre.
From the west, the centre is accessed from Castle Street (A4161), Wood Street and Penarth Road (A4160), with St. Mary's Street connecting the three, but is restricted to no{{nbhyph}}car traffic. Penarth Road terminates at Callaghan Square.
From the south, Lloyd George Avenue (A470), Bute Street and the Central Link (A4234) originate from [[Cardiff Bay]] and meet the city centre at Callaghan Square.
==Transport in the city centre== {{see also|Transport in Cardiff}}
===Bus=== The vast majority of [[Cardiff Bus]] services run to or through the city centre, approaching from the west along either Tudor Street or Westgate Street, from the north along North Road or Newport Road, from the east along Newport Road and from the south along Callaghan Square. Most services circle the city centre, creating a "bus box". Some terminate or pass through [[Cardiff Central bus station]], off Wood Street, which is currently being redeveloped. Other major interchanges include The Hayes, Dumfries Place, Westgate Street, Greyfriars Road and St. Mary Street, with taxi stands being located next to most of these.
The [[Baycar]] service circles the city centre every 10 minutes before continuing to [[Cardiff Bay]].
===Rail=== [[File:CardiffCentral-front-02.jpg|thumb|right|Cardiff Central station]] [[File:Cardiff Queen Street station April 2009.JPG|thumb|right|Cardiff Queen Street station]]
The city centre is served by two railway stations. [[Cardiff Queen Street]] is in the east of the centre and is the city's main hub for urban services to the rest of Cardiff, its [[South Wales Valleys|valleys]] and the [[Vale of Glamorgan]]. [[Cardiff Central railway station|Cardiff Central]], located in the south of the city centre, is the largest station in the city and one of the busiest in the United Kingdom, focusing on mainline services. Central railway station is located next to Central bus station forming an interchange.
[[Cathays railway station]], [[Grangetown railway station]] and [[Ninian Park railway station]] are all within {{convert|1.5|mi|km}} of the centre serving edges of the city centre.
===Road=== The [[A470 road|A470]] bypasses the centre to the east running southbound to [[Cardiff Bay]] and northbound to [[Cardiff North (geographical area)|North Cardiff]], [[Pontypridd]], [[Merthyr Tydfil]] and [[Brecon]]. The A470 road meets the [[A4232 road|A4232]] at [[Cardiff Bay]], leading to [[Culverhouse Cross]] and the [[M4 motorway]], and also meets the [[A48 road|A48 Camarthen–Gloucester road]] at [[Gabalfa]], north of the centre.
Some city centre taxis can be hailed. They are usually, but not always, black with a white bonnet or hackney carriages.
===Water=== The [[Cardiff Waterbus]] has stops at Cardiff Castle and Taff Mead Embankment, next to the [[Millennium Stadium]], with services to [[Cardiff Bay]].
===Cycle=== A cycle hire system, similar to those in other large cities, launched in September 2009, and included 70 bikes and 35 hire points (initially 7) around the centre and the south of the city. The cycle hire system was shut down in 2012. <ref>{{cite web | title = Public bike hire scheme for city | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/wales/south_east/8267199.stm | work = BBC News | publisher = BBC | date = {{date| 22 sep 2009}} | accessdate = {{date| 9 mar 2013}} }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/cardiff-news/2009/09/22/smart-bike-system-launch-91466-24747392/ | title = Smart bike system launch | last = Aylford | first = Abby | accessdate = {{date| 9 mar 2013}} | publisher = Welsh Media Ltd | date = {{date|22 sep 2009}} | work = South Wales Echo }}</ref>

[[File:Zhang Bishi.jpg|thumb|Cheong Fatt Tze]]
'''Cheong Fatt Tze''' or '''Tjong Tjen Hsoen''' ({{zh|s=张弼士|zh|t=張弼士|p=Zhāng Bìshì}}; 1840 – 1916) was a Chinese businessman and politician. He was a powerful [[Nanyang (region)|Nanyang]] industrialist and a first-class [[Mandarin (bureaucrat)|Mandarin]] in the Manchu government; he was made Consul-General in Singapore and economic advisor to the Empress Dowager.
==Early life== He was born in 1840 in [[Dabu County|Dabu]], [[Guangdong Province]] in South [[China]]. As he came from a poor [[Hakka people|Hakka]] family, he started working at an early age as a cowherd back in his village. In 1856, [[Taiping Rebellion|civil war]] ravaged much of China, and in that same year another war had broken out between the [[Emperor of China]] and the [[England|English]], known as the [[Second Opium War]] (1856–1862). The people had experienced hardship and suffering during the war. As a result, Cheong Fatt Tze migrated to [[South-East Asia]] together with other coastal Chinese families to seek their fortune.
==Career== He started as a water-carrier and then became a shopkeeper in [[Jakarta]], [[Indonesia]]. After his marriage, he established a trading company with the help of his father-in-law. Gradually, he began to accumulate his wealth through hard work and perseverance. In 1877, he expanded his business from [[Jakarta]] to [[Medan]]. His business was based on [[agricultural]] products such as [[rubber]], [[coffee]] and [[tea]] but he branched out to the financial sector by acquiring a bank. This move made him a wealthy man.
In 1886, he expanded again to [[Penang]], [[Malaysia]]. As his business grew, he owned three ships which plied between Penang and Medan. In the course of his work, he occasionally resided in Penang and owned a [[Cheong Fatt Tze Mansion|mansion]] in Leith Street, which stands to this day as protected heritage building.
==Political career== In 1890, in recognition of his hard work and contribution, he was appointed the Chinese Consul, based in Penang. This office was shifted to [[Singapore]] when that city became established as a well-known trading port in [[South-East Asia]]. As the Chinese Consul, he worked tirelessly for the interests of overseas Chinese residents through diplomatic channels with the [[British Empire|British]] authorities.
In 1899, he was summoned to China twice by the [[Emperor of China]] and instructed to present a national development plan, which was well received by the government of the [[Qing dynasty]]. As a result, he was promoted to be the Minister for agriculture, industries, roads and mines for the provinces of [[Fujian]] and [[Guangdong]]. Later he was instructed to conduct a study of trade and education in Penang and Singapore. Subsequently, the Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce was established. In 1904, he established the first Chinese school in Southeast Asia, the [[Chung Hwa Confucian School]] in Penang.
In 1912, the [[Kuomintang]] overthrew the Qing and established a [[Republic of China (1912–49)|republican government]]. Cheong was appointed as a member of the Legislative Assembly so that he could be actively involved with politics. He was also appointed as the Chairman of the Chinese national Chamber of Commerce, which was well received by all parties.
In 1915, he was sent to the [[United States]] to study all aspects of industrialization of that nation. During his journey, when he stopped over in [[Hong Kong]], he was awarded a [[Ph.D.]] in [[Law]].
==Death== Cheong Fatt Tze died in [[Indonesia]] in 1916. His body was sent back to China to be buried. On its final journey through Penang, Singapore and Hong Kong, the overseas Chinese were greatly saddened by the loss of this great personality. The Chinese government sent a high-ranking official to his funeral and ordered the National Archives to record his life in historical documents so that his contributions would always be remembered. Both the British and the [[Dutch Empire|Dutch]] authorities ordered flags to be flown at half mast to honour the man who was known as ''"the [[John D. Rockefeller|Rockefeller]] of the East"''. He had eight wives and owned many residences throughout his trading empire (mostly [[Southeast Asia]]) but made Penang his base, where he raised his six sons.
==Legacy== In 1894, [[Chung Keng Quee]] hosted in his own gardens, in the name of Vice Consul Chang, Pi Shih (Cheong Fatt Tze), a dinner to welcome Admiral Ting (see Battle of Yalu River (1894) and Battle of Weihaiwei) and the Chinese Imperial Fleet of warships that he commanded.
Cheong Fatt Tze first introduced grape vineyards in China's Shandong province, and later brought in Austrian wine-producing experts to improve the vineyard in Yantai, Shandong. Cheong Fatt Tze also gave shelter to Sun Yat Sen and Sun Yat Sen 's fourth wife in Penang, Cheong Fatt Tze also helped Sun Yat Sen with Money to promote a Chinese Nationalist movement in China after 1911.
A street in George Town, Penang, which was formerly named Hong Kong Street, was renamed after him, Jalan Cheong Fatt Tze. His blue mansion, [[Cheong Fatt Tze Mansion]], is a heritage building, located at Leith Street in George Town. It is open for guided tours, and also offers accommodation and has an on-site restaurant.<ref>{{cite web|title=Cheong Fatt Tze Mansion|url=http://www.minorsights.com/2016/08/malaysia-cheong-fatt-tze-mansion.html|work=Minor Sights|accessdate=17 August 2016}}</ref> He left another mansion in his birthplace, Dabu, Guangdong Province, China.

{{Infobox Prime Minister | name =Constantin Argetoianu | nationality =[[Romania]]n | smallimage = | image =Argeto.jpg | imagesize =170px | caption = | order =41st [[Prime Minister of Romania]] | term_start =28 September 1939 | term_end =24 November 1939 | monarch =[[Carol II of Romania|Carol II]] | vicepresident = | deputy = | predecessor =[[Gheorghe Argeşanu]] | successor =[[Gheorghe Tătărescu]] | order2 = | term_start2 = | term_end2 = | predecessor2 = | successor2 = | birth_date = 15 March 1871 | birth_place =[[Craiova]], [[Romania]] | death_date ={{death date|1955|2|6|mf=y}} (aged 83) | death_place =[[Sighet]], [[Romania]] | constituency = | party =[[National Renaissance Front]] | spouse = | profession =businessman | religion =[[Romanian Orthodox Church|Romanian Orthodox]] | signature = | footnotes = |}} '''Constantin Argetoianu''' ({{OldStyleDate|15 March|1871|3 March}} – 6 February 1955) was a [[Romania]]n politician, one of the best-known personalities of [[Interwar period|interwar]] [[Greater Romania]], who served as the [[List of Prime Ministers of Romania|Prime Minister]] between 28 September and 23 November 1939. His [[memoirs]], ''Memorii. Pentru cei de mâine. Amintiri din vremea celor de ieri'' ("Memoirs. For those of tomorrow. Recollections of yesterday's world")—a cross section of Romanian society, were made known for the sharp critique of several major figures in Romanian politics (using a sarcastic tone which had made his previous political speeches notorious).<ref>Otu; Slabey Roucek, p.76</ref>
==Biography==
===Early life=== Born in [[Craiova]] as the son of [[Romanian Army|Army]] general [[Ioan Argetoianu]], he trained in Law, Medicine, and Letters at the [[University of Paris]], and later entered the diplomatic service (1897).<ref name="Slabey Roucek, p.76">Slabey Roucek, p.76</ref>
He was an exceptionally prosperous man (a noted [[Bucharest Stock Exchange|Stock Exchange]] player and landowner in [[Breasta]], [[Dolj County]]), and his frequent change in political allegiances was attributed by some of his contemporaries to his financial independence.<ref name="Savu; Slabey Roucek, p.76">Savu; Slabey Roucek, p.76</ref> He served as a [[combat medic]] with the rank of captain in the [[Second Balkan War]], where he faced a [[cholera]] epidemic.<ref>Manolache</ref>
===World War I===
A [[Freemasonry|Freemason]],<ref>Otu</ref> Argetoianu was first elected to the [[Senate of Romania|Senate]] in 1914 as a [[Conservative Party (Romania, 1880-1918)|Conservative Party]] representative,<ref name="Savu; Slabey Roucek, p.76"/> where he oscillated between the dissident the mainstream Conservatives of [[Petre P. Carp]] and the dissident group around [[Take Ionescu]] (the latter was welcoming Romania's entry into [[World War I]] on the side of the [[Allies of World War I|Entente Powers]], which Argetoianu also proposed).<ref>Boia, p.251</ref>
Throughout 1918, during the final stages of the [[Romanian Campaign (World War I)|Romanian Campaign]], Argetoianu was Justice Minister, sitting on the first [[Alexandru Averescu]] cabinet (at the time when authorities had retreated to [[Iaşi]], leaving the southern half of the country to be occupied by [[German Empire|Imperial German]], [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian]] and [[Bulgaria]]n troops).<ref name="Slabey Roucek, p.76"/> He was also head of the Romanian delegation at the Peace preliminaries of [[Buftea]], in 1918. The talks resulted in the [[Treaty of Bucharest, 1918|Treaty of Bucharest]] of May, which consecrated Romania's defeat by the [[Central Powers]]. His actions at the time were later the subject of an [[epigram]] by [[Cincinat Pavelescu]] (Pavelescu expressed his belief that the treaty and Argetoianu's views on fiscal policies were to be the subject of scorn for future generations).<ref>Pavelescu</ref>
===People's Party=== Argetoianu followed Averescu into opposition to the [[Ion I. C. Brătianu]] [[National Liberal Party (Romania, 1875)|National Liberal Party]] (PNL) cabinet, and joined the [[People's Party (interwar Romania)|People's Party]] (PP) created by the latter. He later documented the [[Populism|populist]] message of the movement, and left testimonies of Averescu's spontaneous adulation by the crowds of peasants.<ref>Boia, p.264; Scurtu, "Prăbuşirea unui mit", "Mit şi realitate..."</ref>
Argetoianu was Finance Minister and later [[List of Romanian Ministers of the Interior|Interior Minister]] in the second Averescu government of 1920.<ref>Slabey Roucek, p.76; Troncotă, p.18</ref> In March 1921, it was uncovered that an associate of his named Aron Schuller had attempted to contract a 20 million [[Italian lira|lire]] loan with a bank in [[Italy]], using as [[Collateral (finance)|collateral]] Romanian [[war bond]]s that he had illegally obtained from the Finance Ministry reserve.<ref>Constantinescu, p.68</ref> Argetoianu, who was still in charge at the time, became the target of attacks from the opposition group formed by the [[Romanian National Party]] and the [[Peasants' Party (Romania)|Peasants' Party]], being pressed by [[Virgil Madgearu]] and [[Grigore Iunian]] to explain himself (Iunian proposed a [[motion of no confidence]], but the PNL continued to show its support for the PP).<ref>Constantinescu, p.68–70</ref>
===Clash with Communism and split with Averescu=== Argetoianu soon became noted for his [[Anti-Communism|anti-communist]] stance: he carried out arrests of those [[Socialist Party of Romania|Socialist Party]] members who, during their party's congress in May 1921, supported a [[Maximum programme|maximalist platform]] and voted in favor of aligning their Socialist-Communist faction (future [[Romanian Communist Party|Communist Party of Romania]]) with the [[Comintern]], citing the latter's condemnation of [[Greater Romania]] (all those arrested were prosecuted in the [[Dealul Spirii Trial]]).<ref>Diac; Troncotă, p.18–19</ref> Argetoianu later stated that the arrest lacked legal grounds, and indicated that he purposely gave the Socialist [[Gheorghe Cristescu]] approval to hold the congress as a means to incriminate the faction.<ref name="Diac">Diac</ref> Faced with mixed reactions inside the cabinet (Averescu hesitated, while the Minister of Justice [[Grigore Trancu-Iași]] refused to give him support), he ordered the move without his fellow ministers' prior knowledge, and thus faced them with a ''[[fait accompli]]''.<ref name="Diac"/>
The standoff between Averescu and the parliamentary opposition eventually witnessed a decisive incident: during a prolonged debate over Averescu's proposal to [[Nationalization|nationalize]] enterprises in [[Reşiţa]], Argetoianu addressed a mumbled insult to Madgearu; the PNL, seeing an opportunity for a return to power, expressed sympathy, and all opposition groups appealed to Ferdinand, asking for Averescu's recall (July 14, 1921).<ref name="Scurtu, Prăbuşirea unui mit">Scurtu, "Prăbuşirea unui mit"</ref>
Despite Averescu's eventual defeat in December 1921, Argetoianu was kept in office by the [[Take Ionescu]] and Brătianu cabinets. During the spring of 1922, he ordered the killing of several Communist activists who were held in prison custody, including [[Leonte Filipescu]], staging their attempts to flee from under escort as a pretext.<ref>Troncotă, p.18–19</ref> Nevertheless, pressures on the revolutionary grouping were relaxed in summer, when [[King of Romania|King]] [[Ferdinand I of Romania|Ferdinand I]] approved an [[amnesty]] and Argetoianu officially declared that "communism is over in Romania".<ref>Argetoianu, in Diac; in Troncotă, p.19</ref>
===PND and PNL=== In 1923, after Brătianu again assumed power, he clashed with Averescu and proclaimed himself leader of the PP, being eventually expelled.<ref name="Scurtu, Prăbuşirea unui mit"/> Having joined [[Nicolae Iorga]]'s [[Democratic Nationalist Party (Romania)|Democratic Nationalist Party]] (PND), he soon vehemently protested against the latter's alliance with the Romanian National Party, and moved to the PNL.<ref name="Slabey Roucek, p.76"/>
Following the sudden death of Ion I. C. Brătianu in 1927, and choosing, in contrast to the policies of [[Dinu Brătianu]], to support the new King [[Carol II of Romania|Carol II]] in 1930, Argetoianu left the party and subsequently defined himself as an independent.<ref name="Slabey Roucek, p.76"/> In effect, he moved into the camp of politicians approving of an [[Authoritarianism|authoritarian]] regime around Carol.<ref name="Veiga, p.130">Veiga, p.130</ref> As the monarch's relations with the traditional political class were souring, Argetoianu allegedly engaged in a campaign to draw new allegiances from other environments, aiding to establish a Romanian ''[[Camarilla (history)|camarilla]]'' — it was even reported that, using the official commitment to neutral [[Technocracy (bureaucratic)|technocracy]] as a means to appoint his choice of people to positions of influence, he had recruited his fellow [[Bucharest]] [[Jockey Club of Bucharest|Jockey Club]] members.<ref name="Veiga, p.130"/> Among his most vocal supporters at the time was the [[far right]] philosopher [[Nae Ionescu]].<ref>Ornea, p.226; Veiga, p.200</ref>
===Iorga cabinet and Agrarian Party=== He was again in charge of Internal Affairs and Finance from 1931 to 1932, during the Iorga government,<ref>Slabey Roucek, p.76; Veiga, p.137–138</ref> when he took a harsh stance against the [[Fascism|fascist]] [[Iron Guard]], outlawing it and arresting some of its members (which led to a string of violent confrontations).<ref>Ornea, p.295, 296; Veiga, p.137</ref> Argetoianu was hotly contested as Finance Minister: faced with the widespread [[insolvency]] of small agricultural holdings in front of the [[Great Depression]], he proposed a form of [[liquidation]] that was considered in breach of the [[1923 Constitution of Romania|1923 Constitution]].<ref>Veiga, p.130, 140–141</ref> Various other issues forced Argetoianu to cease payments of salaries for [[Civil service|civil servants]] at certain intervals, causing far-reaching problems.<ref>Veiga, p.156</ref>
The government was voted out of office in the elections of 1932, when Iorga was replaced by [[Alexandru Vaida-Voevod]], a member of the [[National Peasants' Party]] (PNŢ) who was himself challenged with solving the agrarian issue;<ref>Veiga, p.138, 141</ref> Argetoianu subsequently founded the minor [[Agrarian Union Party]], which, after the National Liberals returned to power with [[Ion G. Duca]], remained a close associate of the king in his competition with traditional forces; when Duca was assassinated by the Iron Guard in the final days of 1933, Argetoianu, together with his former adversary, PNŢ dissident [[Grigore Iunian]], and the [[National Agrarian Party (Romania)|National Agrarian Party]]'s [[Octavian Goga]], was probably one of the king's main options in his attempt to create an altogether new political establishment around the ''camarilla'', relying on a compromise with [[Corneliu Zelea Codreanu]] (leader of the Iron Guard).<ref>Veiga, p.202, 209, 215</ref> Codreanu refused to accept negotiation, but Carol successfully approached the PNL's "young liberals" faction, which came to power with [[Gheorghe Tătărescu]] (January 1934).<ref>Veiga, p.202</ref>
===Royal dictatorship and World War II=== The frequent target of attacks in the Iron Guard press,<ref>Ornea, p.243, 245</ref> Argetoianu led his grouping until 1938, when, faced with the unstoppable rise of the Iron Guard, Carol banned all parties and established his [[National Renaissance Front]] (FRN).<ref>Argetoianu, "Pleacă Tătărescu, vine Gigurtu"; Veiga, p.215</ref>
His own short-lived FRN cabinet, established after that date, was, after [[Gheorghe Argeşanu]]'s the second in quick succession to the violent clash between the Guard and monarch (after the murder of [[Armand Călinescu]] by the former). The Argetoianu government was replaced by that of Tătărescu, who had to deal with the [[Soviet Union]]'s [[Soviet occupation of Bessarabia|occupation of Bessarabia]] and was in turn replaced with [[Ion Gigurtu]]<ref>Argetoianu, "Pleacă Tătărescu, vine Gigurtu"</ref> (Argetoianu, who remained influential throughout the period, began calling for a rapprochement between Romania and the Soviets).<ref name="ReferenceA">Otu</ref>
Carol's regime crumbled after the [[Second Vienna Award]], when Romania had to cede [[Northern Transylvania]] to [[Hungary]]; it was replaced by the Iron Guard's [[National Legionary State]], which, itself repressed during the previous years, began a campaign of retaliation — like Tătărescu and several others, Argetoianu was kidnapped on November 27, 1940 in the wake of the [[Jilava Massacre]], and faced assassination until being rescued by the intervention of [[Romanian Army]] officials.<ref>Veiga, p.292, 309</ref>
Retreating from public life during [[World War II]] and the [[Ion Antonescu]] dictatorship (''see [[Romania during World War II]]''), Argetoianu left the country in the spring of 1944, settling in [[Switzerland]].<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Romania's withdrawal from the [[Axis Powers|Axis]] and the start of [[Soviet occupation of Romania|Soviet occupation]] caused him to return in November, seeing an opportunity in the apparent decrease in the appeal of traditional parties and expanding on his vision of Romanian-Soviet cooperation.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> He was the subject of derision in the [[National Peasants' Party]] press (''[[Dreptatea]]'' wrote of him: "leading the intrigue in favor of a [[private property]]–based [[communism]], a [[Capitalism|capitalist]]-based [[socialism]], a [[Working class|mass]]-free [[democracy]]... The country is trustingly placing itself at your disposal. Here are your strings: pull them! Here are your back rooms: maneuver them! Here is your «people»: take it away!").<ref>"Profilo", in Otu</ref>
===UNMR, arrest, and death===
Attempting in vain to mediate between the Communists and the PNȚ, Argetoianu was rejected by both sides, and, in January 1947, formed his own grouping — the ''National Union for Work and Reconstruction'' (''Uniunea Națională Muncă și Refacere'', UNMR) —, alongside [[Nicolae Ottescu]], [[Nicolae D. Cornățeanu]], [[Zamfir Brătescu]] and others.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> It was kept under surveillance by the Communist-controlled [[Petru Groza]] government, and was infiltrated by the pro-Communist ''National-Agrarian Action'' (''Acțiunea Național-Agrară'', ANA).<ref name="ReferenceA"/> The UNMR disbanded over worries that Argetoianu was losing credibility with Soviet authorities—the group around Cornățeanu joined Premier Groza's [[Ploughmen's Front]], while others entered the [[Union of Patriots (Romania)|Union of Patriots]].<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
Argetoianu, who was ill at the time and had just undergone surgery on his [[prostate]], withdrew from public life for a second time.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Two years after a [[Communist Romania|Communist regime]] was imposed on Romania, on the morning of May 6, 1950, he was arrested by the [[Securitate]]; while being taken away, he was heard saying: "Man, you sure are tough, you communists, if you are afraid of a farting old man such as myself".<ref>Argetoianu, in Otu</ref> He died in the infamous [[Sighet prison]] five years later,<ref>* {{citation | last = Giurescu | first = Constantin C. | year = 1994 | title = Cinci ani și două luni în penitenciarul din Sighet (7 mai 1950 – 5 iulie 1955) | publisher = Editura Fundației Culturale Române | place = București }}</ref><ref>{{citation | last = Neagoe | first = Stelian | year = 2012 | title = Politică și destin. Constantin Argetoianu | publisher = Editura Machiavelli | authorlink = Stelian Neagoe |place= București }}</ref> never having been put on trial. In 1999, attorney and civil rights activist [[Monica Macovei]], representing Argetoianu's two granddaughters - Yvonne Oroveanu Niculescu and Constantina "Dina" Oroveanu - before court cleared Argetoianu of all charges, with prosecutor Carp admitting that Argetoianu's detention had been an abuse.<ref>{{citation | date = 1999 | title = A încetat urmarirea penală împotriva fostului prim-ministru Constantin Argetoianu | newspaper = Evenimentul Zilei | url = http://www.evz.ro/detalii/stiri/a-incetat-urmarirea-penala-impotriva-fostului-prim-ministru-constantin-argetoianu-567864.html | accessdate = August 8, 2013 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140330193854/http://www.evz.ro/detalii/stiri/a-incetat-urmarirea-penala-impotriva-fostului-prim-ministru-constantin-argetoianu-567864.html | archivedate = March 30, 2014 | df = }}</ref>
