{{distinguish|Petri Nygård}} {{multiple issues| {{COI|date=October 2018}} {{autobiography|date=October 2018}} {{too few opinions|date=May 2016}} }} {{Infobox person |name = Peter Nygård |image = Peter Nygard 2016.jpg |caption = Peter Nygård, Beverly Hills, California on February 28, 2016 |birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1943}} |birth_place = [[Helsinki]], [[Finland]] |citizenship = Canadian |residence = [[The Bahamas]] |occupation = Business owner |known_for = Founder and Chairman of
[[Nygård International]] }} '''Peter J. Nygård''' (born 1943) is a [[Finnish Canadians|Finnish-Canadian]] [[clothing|fashion]] executive, founder and chairman of [[Nygård International]], a company based in [[Winnipeg]] that makes women's wear. He was rated the 70th richest Canadian by ''[[Canadian Business Magazine]]'' in 2009 with a net worth of $817 million {{cite web|last=Kirbyson |first=Geoff |url=http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/breakingnews/manitobans-make-magazines-rich-100-list-70447987.html |title=Manitobans make magazine's Rich 100 list |publisher=Winnipeg Free Press |date=2009-11-19 |accessdate=2010-04-14}}, but he is not shown on the Canadian Business ranking of the 100 wealthiest individuals and families in Canada 2018 list [https://www.canadianbusiness.com/lists-and-rankings/richest-people/100-richest-canadians-complete-list/] ==Early life and education== Nygård was born in [[Helsinki]], [[Finland]] in 1943. His parents were Eeli and Hilkka Nygård, bakers who immigrated to [[Canada]] in 1952, settling at first in [[Deloraine, Manitoba]] (where [[Nygård Park]] would later be named in his honour in 2002). They moved shortly after to [[Winnipeg]].http://www4.nygard.com/uploadedFiles/News/YEAR_2010/News_2010/full_HilkkaNygard_new.pdf In 1964, he graduated from the [[University of North Dakota]] with a business degree.http://www4.nygard.com/scf/News2003.aspx?id=357{{cite web |url= http://www.innovators.net/innovators/public_html/about_the_center/entrepreneur_hall.html |title= North Dakota Entrepreneur Hall of Fame |publisher= innovators.net |accessdate= 12 July 2010 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20110429024652/http://www.innovators.net/innovators/public_html/about_the_center/entrepreneur_hall.html |archive-date= 2011-04-29 |dead-url= yes |df= }}{{cite web |url= http://www.innovators.net/innovators/public_html/about_the_center/entrepreneur_awards.html |title= Entrepreneur Awards |publisher= innovators.net |accessdate= 12 July 2011 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20110701145531/http://www.innovators.net/innovators/public_html/about_the_center/entrepreneur_awards.html |archive-date= 2011-07-01 |dead-url= yes |df= }} ==Tan Jay== On December 1, 1967, Nygård started working as sales manager for a new jeans line of a woman’s clothing manufacturer Jacob Fashions . A few weeks later Nygård used his life [[savings]] of $8,000 and an additional [[loan]] to purchase 20% of the company from the founder Nathan Jacob. A few years later, Nygård bought the rest of the company from Jacobs daughters and renamed it Tan Jay.[http://jonesbahamas.com/the-opportunity-that-led-to-a-fortune/] Nygård apparel manufacturing company was founded in 1967 in [[Winnipeg]], Manitoba. Its Canada headquarters is now in [[Toronto]], Ontario with its world headquarters in [[Times Square]], [[New York City|New York]].{{cite web|url=http://corporate.nygard.com/company-profile/?ID=31&Folder_id=14 |title=Nygard International Company Profile}} Nygård's fashion concept retail store opened in [[Times Square]] in [[Manhattan]] on Friday, November 6, 2009. ==Nygård Cay== In 1987, Nygård built a {{convert|150000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} compound at [[Lyford Cay]] in the Bahamas. It was partly destroyed by a fire on November 10, 2009.[http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/breakingnews/Fire-destroys-Nygards-Bahamas-compound-69911722.html "Fire destroys Nygard's Bahamas compound"], [[Winnipeg Free Press]], November 10, 2009 The Cay is inspired by the [[Mayan civilization]]’s architecture. One of the major buildings is a 32,000 ft2 grand-hall with a 100,000 lb glass ceiling.{{cite web|url=http://www.unusualvillarentals.com/caribbean/bahamas/nygard/|title=Nygård Cay|publisher=unusualvillarentals.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100626100416/http://www.unusualvillarentals.com/caribbean/bahamas/nygard/|archive-date=2010-06-26|dead-url=yes|accessdate=28 June 2010|df=}} On April 14, 2010 Peter Nygard announced he was planning a $50 million renovation of Nygård Cay, which would take two years to complete and repair the damage and employ 200 construction workers.{{cite web|url=http://www.thenassauguardian.com/bixex/325682364938194.php|title=Nygard pledges 50 million comeback|publisher=[[List of newspapers in the Bahamas|The Nassau Guardian]]|accessdate=June 28, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100627081222/http://www.thenassauguardian.com/bixex/325682364938194.php|archive-date=2010-06-27|dead-url=yes|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.tribune242.com/searchresults/16082010_nkn-nygard-no-license_news_pg1|title=Nygard Cay is not licensed as commercial property|publisher=The Nassau Tribune|date=August 16, 2010|accessdate=August 31, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100822030630/http://www.tribune242.com/searchresults/16082010_nkn-nygard-no-license_news_pg1|archive-date=2010-08-22|dead-url=yes|df=}} But a letter from the Bahamian prime minister's office rejected his construction application, citing the improper expansion of his property through intentional accretion of land over the seabed. On September 28, 2018 Nygård Cay was seized by the Supreme Court of the Bahamas as part of a legal battle surrounding Nygard’s efforts to dredge the sea floor around the estate [https://theworldnews.net/ca-news/peter-nygard-locked-out-of-his-luxury-home-in-bizarre-bahamas-feud] ==Charity== Nygård has supported the [[Canadian Breast Cancer Foundation]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cnwtelbec.com/en/releases/archive/September2007/30/c6818.html?view=print |title=$26.5 million Raised Nationwide as Canadian Breast Cancer Foundation CIBC Run for the Cure Celebrates Sweet Sixteen |publisher=Cnwtelbec.com |date= |accessdate=2010-04-14}} Nygård has been a longtime sponsor of amateur sports in the Bahamas. In June 2010, is the main sponsor of [[Amateur Boxing Federation of the Bahamas]]' team for Continental Elite Boxing Championships Invitation only event slated for June 13–19 in [[Quito]], Ecuador.{{cite web|url=http://www.tribune242.com/sports/06012010_Nygardsponsorship_sports|title=Nygard sponsoring team for 'invitation only' amateur boxing event|publisher=The Tribune|date=June 1, 2010|accessdate=June 29, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717100937/http://www.tribune242.com/sports/06012010_Nygardsponsorship_sports|archive-date=2011-07-17|dead-url=yes|df=}} Wellington Miller, the president of the [[Bahamas Olympic Committee]], said Nygård has contributed significantly to the Amateur Boxing Association of the Bahamas and their Olympic success.{{cite web|url=http://www.tribune242.com/sports/03292011_Gibsonhonored_sports|title=Nygard to sponsor Exuma regatta|publisher=The Tribune|date=March 29, 2011|accessdate=April 13, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120315023708/http://www.tribune242.com/sports/03292011_Gibsonhonored_sports|archive-date=2012-03-15|dead-url=yes|df=}} In April 2011, Nygård held the "2011 National Family Island Regatta" at Nygård Cay, which included a press conference to honor Bahamian musician "King" [[Eric Gibson]].{{cite web|url=http://www.jonesbahamas.com/news/123/ARTICLE/22793/2011-03-28.html|title=Nygard Does It Again, Sponsors National F.I. Regatta|publisher=Jones Bahamas|date=March 28, 2011|accessdate=April 13, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.tribune242.com/03292011_Gibsonpleased_sports|title=I did everything that I could to make it such a great sport|publisher=The Tribune|date=March 29, 2011|accessdate=April 13, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110429134904/http://www.tribune242.com/03292011_Gibsonpleased_sports|archive-date=2011-04-29|dead-url=yes|df=}} In the same month, Nygård also donated $10,000 to Josie Poitier, a member of [[Old Holy Redeemer Catholic Church]], during a Passover/Good Friday Breakfast/Brunch.{{cite web|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2011/04/25/2184586/after-years-of-giving-volunteer.html|title=After years of giving, volunteer gets recognition, reward|publisher=Miami Herald|date=April 25, 2011|accessdate=April 25, 2011}}{{failed verification|date=August 2014}} ==Lawsuits== Nygård has been accused of [[Abuse|abusive]] labor practices, [[tax evasion]], [[sexual harassment]] and [[rape]].{{cite web|title=Peter Nygard Answers to No One|last=Falkenberg|first=Kai|url=https://www.forbes.com/forbes/2010/1206/features-peter-nygard-sexual-harassment-answers-to-no-one.html#52f40c70bc9b|date=November 18, 2010|publisher=Forbes Media LLC|access-date=October 16, 2018}} *In 1978, Nygård's takeover of a sportswear designer's business in New York City led to a 12-year legal battle in New York federal court. *In 1980, the ''Free Press'' wrote that Nygård was charged with the rape of an 18-year-old girl by Winnipeg authorities. Later those charges were dropped. *Nygård [[Settlement (litigation)|settled]] sexual harassment complaints by three former employees in Manitoba in the late 1990s. *In 1999, Nygård sued [[Linda Brava|Linda Lampenius]] for defamation when she claimed that he hired lookalikes for his [[Oscar party]] and "defrauded the entertainment industry and international press". The case was settled with Lampenius printing an apology in the Finnish press. *In 2003, Nygård was sued in Florida by an American couple who claimed he deceived them into accepting jobs as managers of his Bahamas estate. The case was settled in 2007. *In 2006, Canadian tax authorities claimed Nygård underreported $15 million in taxes. Nygård argued that he severed residential ties with Canada in 1975; he was ultimately subject to taxes on an unreported $2 million.
In 2007 with a bit of irritation over runoff has escalated to a battle royal encompassing no fewer than 16 [[Legal action|legal actions]] between Nygård and [[Louis Bacon|Luis Bacon]] and their associates, in which both sides are claiming damages in the tens of millions of dollars and lobbing allegations of activities that include [[vandalism]], [[bribery]], [[insider trading]], [[arson]], [[murder]], destruction of the fragile seabed, and having a close association with the [[Ku Klux Klan]]. Bacon v. Nygard, 150400/2015, New York State Supreme Court, New York County{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-04-24/billionaire-bacon-s-defamation-suit-against-nygard-reinstated}}
*In 2008, Nygård was sued in Los Angeles Superior Court by a former girlfriend for slamming a door on her hand. Nygård quickly settled the lawsuit.
In 2012, Nygård launched a lawsuit against the [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC]] regarding copyright issues about private videos taken at his residence, which were then used in an April 2010 documentary.{{cite web|url=http://www.lfpress.com/news/canada/2012/02/23/19417251.html|title=Nygard files another lawsuit against CBC|publisher=lfpress.com|date=2012-02-23|access-date=2012-02-24}}{{cite web|url=http://www.tribune242.com/sports/04142010_alnygard_news_pg1|title=Former Deputy PM denies defending Nygard International against immigration accusations|publisher=The Nassau Tribune|date=April 14, 2010|access-date=April 20, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717100200/http://www.tribune242.com/sports/04142010_alnygard_news_pg1|archive-date=2011-07-17|dead-url=yes|df=}} He had also launched a copyright complaint with the US District Court in New York{{cite web |url=http://www.fftimes.com/node/230384 |title=Fashion mogul Peter Nygård tries to block airing of CBC show |publisher=Fftimes.com |date=2010-01-12 |access-date=2010-04-14 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100426002443/http://www.fftimes.com/node/230384 |archive-date=2010-04-26 |dead-url=yes |df= }}{{cite web|author=Famous Fashionista says: |url=http://www.fashionmagazine.com/blogs/fashion/fashion-news/2010/01/11/nygard-seeks-damages-from-the-cbc/ |title=Nygård seeks damages from the CBC |publisher=fashionmagazine.com |date=2010-01-11 |access-date=2010-04-14}}{{cite web|last=Austen |first=Ian |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/11/business/media/11nygard.html?partner=rss&emc=rss |title=Nygard Sues Over Unwanted Media Coverage |location=Canada |publisher=NYTimes.com |date=2010-01-10 |access-date=2010-04-14}} and a lawsuit in Manitoba to prevent the piece from airing.{{cite web|last=Owen |first=Bruce |url=http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/local/cbc-probe-distracts-staff-nygard-claims-81304202.html |title=CBC probe distracts staff, Nygård claims |publisher=Winnipeg Free Press |date=2010-01-13 |access-date=2010-04-14}} He had previously sued two former employees for releasing confidential information and his lawyer claimed CBC harassed many of the employees. Nygård launched a civil suit against his neighbor and the Lyford Cay Property Owners Association alleging they conspired with the CBC to damage his reputation; he also filed a private criminal prosecution against three CBC journalists accusing them of conspiring to discredit him and his clothing empire.{{cite web|url=http://www.torontosun.com/news/canada/2011/04/09/17935196.html|title=Nygard enemy bolts|publisher=Toronto Sun|date=4/9/2011|access-date=2011-04-26}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/fashion-tycoon-peter-nygard-files-criminal-complaint-against-cbc/article1966340/|title=Fashion tycoon Peter Nygard files criminal complaint against CBC|publisher=Toronto Sun|date=4/1/2011|access-date=2011-04-26}}
==Personal life== Nygård currently lives in [[Nassau, Bahamas]]. He has seven children by four women.http://www.fact.on.ca/news/news0210/np021015.htmhttp://www4.nygard.com/scf/News2003.aspx?id=356 He has been married one time, briefly, in the 1970s, to a model.https://www.forbes.com/forbes/2010/1206/features-peter-nygard-sexual-harassment-answers-to-no-one.html He dated [[Anna Nicole Smith]] for several years. He fathered a daughters Alia and Bianca and son Kai, with Patricia Bickle.http://www.winnipegsun.com/2011/08/02/winnipegs-royal-wedding He fathered a son, Mika, with Kaarina Pakka of [[Oakville, Ontario]]. ===Aircraft=== Nygård owns the following [[Boeing 727|Boeing 727-17]] (VP-BPZ) aircraft for personal and corporate use:http://www.planespotters.net/Aviation_Photos/photo.show?id=306953 "Peter Nygård's Aircraft"

The US [[FAA]]'s '''Pilot Proficiency Award Program''' (Wings) promotes [[air safety]] and encourages [[general aviation]] pilots to continue training and maintain proficiency. All of this in an effort to prevent aircraft accidents. The program features two aspects, knowledge and flight. The knowledge portion presents online courses to maintain or increase an airman's knowledge. The courses are at a quality level found in college, air carrier or military education presentations. The flight portion provides an opportunity to practice and perform selected maneuvers to the standards found in the FAA Flight Test Guide for the certificate level you hold or choose to exercise. (Example: A retired airline pilot with an Airline Transport Pilot certificate may elect to perform at the Private Pilot level for the purposes of satisfying the Wings Program requirements.)
The Program is available to all through the [http://www.faasafety.gov FAA Safety Team Web site]; knowledge provided through the program is free of charge.
==Proficiency phases==
* Basic * Advanced—For those who wish to maintain a higher level of proficiency than required by the Basic level. * Master—For those who wish to maintain the highest level of proficiency. <ref>[http://www.faasafety.gov/documents/Wings_Manual.pdf FAA Advisory Circular 61-91J] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161225063055/http://www.faasafety.gov/documents/Wings_Manual.pdf |date=December 25, 2016 }}</ref><ref>FAA Order 8900.1, Flight Standards Information Management System (FSIMS),Volume 5, Chapter 2, Section 11</ref>
===Legacy program=== [[Image:FAA-Wings-P1.jpg|right|thumb|Phase 1 pin (discontinued design)]][[Image:FAA-Wings-P2.jpg|right|thumb|Phase 2 pin (discontinued design)]] As laid out in Advisory Circular 61-91H,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.faasafety.gov/about/AC61-91H.pdf|format=pdf|title=Pilot Proficiency Award Program|publisher=Federal Aviation Administration|date=April 26, 1996}}</ref> (obsolete, superseded by AC61-91J) the program offered twenty phases and offered you a twenty-year recurrent training opportunity. Participants were eligible for more wings every year after earning their first set, each added set marking progress.
From the program's inception in 1996 until 2007, each of the first 10 phases of the program awarded a pin and a certificate. : * Phase 1 wings are plain [[Bronze (color)|bronze color]]. * Phase 2 wings are [[Silver (color)|silver color]] with a star added. * Phase 3 wings are [[Gold (color)|gold color]] with a star and wreath. * Phase 4 wings are gold tone and have a simulated [[ruby]] mounted in the shield. * Phase 5 wings are gold tone with a rhinestone mounted in the shield. * Phase 6 wings are gold tone with a simulated [[sapphire]] mounted in the shield. * Phase 7, 8, and 9 wings are gold tone with the appropriate [[Roman numeral]] displayed within the wreath. * Phase 10 wings are bright gold tone with the Roman numeral X and shield located within a ring of 10 stars. Past phase 10, only a certificate is awarded.
[[Seaplane]] pilots who specify “seawings” on the proficiency award application get a distinctive set of seawings.
===Program updates=== [[Image:FAASTeamWings-New3.jpg|right|thumb|The new three pins offered by the FAA for the program|250px]] The original Wings program was updated in 2007.<ref>[http://www.faa.gov/safety/awards/wings/ FAA Website describing the changes] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080129052119/http://www.faa.gov/safety/awards/wings/ |date=January 29, 2008 }}</ref> It was replaced by a new program from the new FAA.<ref>[http://www.faasafety.gov safety website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161130012424/http://www.faasafety.gov/ |date=November 30, 2016 }}</ref> This new program attempts to provide better standards for pilots getting flight reviews and training, adding the most common causes of accidents into the curriculum and providing set standards for maneuvers, instead of giving a minimum flight time to complete.
While the [[FAA]] does provide pins for completion of a level of the new Wings program under the updated program,<ref>[http://www.faasafety.gov/articulate/wings/default.htm FAA on-line tutorial describing new program] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080311133403/http://www.faasafety.gov/articulate/wings/default.htm |date=March 11, 2008 }}</ref> it has entered into a partnership with aviation insurer [[Avemco]] where is announced that Avemco will continue to sponsor the WINGS Pilot Proficiency Program by supplying all WINGS participants with WINGS lapel pins upon program completion.<ref>[http://www.avemco.com/Page/NewsRoom-PressReleases-Article17.aspx Avemco press release]{{dead link|date=January 2013}} - AVEMCO ANNOUNCES SUPPORT FOR GENERAL AVIATION PROGRAMS FAA WINGS Program, AERI Research and Build A Plane to Benefit</ref> The FAA does, however, intend to keep track of a pilot's recurrent training and will be able to remind the pilot by e-mail if their training is close to expiring, requiring them to get a new [[biennial flight review|flight review]] or complete another Wings course via a website link.
On 24 September 2010 the program was further updated to include specific recognition for those sea-rated pilots who complete a phase of WINGS in a seaplane or amphibian plane. The [[Seaplane Pilots Association]] agreed to send a lapel pin to these pilots, and some insurance companies have started to offer "significant premium discounts" to members of the Association who complete a phase of WINGS in a seaplane.<ref>[http://www.faasafety.gov/SPANS/noticeView.aspx?nid=2567 FAASafety.gov] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306201957/http://www.faasafety.gov/SPANS/noticeView.aspx?nid=2567 |date=March 6, 2016 }} - "Sea WINGS" notice</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20161130012424/https://www.faasafety.gov/ FAA Safety Website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20161222234937/https://www.faasafety.gov/about/ac61-91h.pdf FAA Advisory Circular 61-91H: Pilot Proficiency Award Program (PDF)]

{{Infobox settlement | name = Quartier international de Montréal | official_name = | settlement_type = [[List of neighbourhoods in Montreal|Neighbourhood]] <!-- Images --> | image_skyline = QuartierInternational2.JPG | image_caption = [[Victoria Square, Montreal|Victoria Square]], with Centre CDP Capital's W Hotel on the left. | image_flag = | image_seal = Quartier international logo.png | motto = <!-- Maps --> | image_map = | map_caption = | pushpin_map = Canada Montreal | pushpin_label_position = bottom | pushpin_map_caption = Location of Quartier international in [[Montreal]] | coordinates = {{coord|45.501236|N|73.561202|W|region:CA-QC|format=dms|display=inline,title}} <!-- Location --> | subdivision_type = [[List of sovereign states|Country]] | subdivision_name = [[Canada]] | subdivision_type1 = Province | subdivision_name1 = [[Quebec]] | subdivision_type2 = City | subdivision_name2 = [[Montreal]] | subdivision_type3 = [[Boroughs of Montreal|Borough]] | subdivision_name3 = [[Ville-Marie, Montreal|Ville-Marie]] | established_title = | established_date = | government_type = | government_footnotes = | leader_title = | leader_name = <!-- Area --> | unit_pref = Metric | area_footnotes = | area_total_km2 = | area_land_km2 = | area_water_km2 = | elevation_footnotes = | elevation_m = <!-- Population --> | population_footnotes = | population_total = | population_as_of = | population_density_km2 = <!-- General information --> | timezone = | utc_offset = | timezone_DST = | utc_offset_DST = <!-- Area/postal codes & others --> | postal_code_type = | postal_code = | area_code = | website = | footnotes = }} The '''Quartier international de Montréal''' ('''QIM''') or '''Montreal's International District''' is a district of the [[Ville-Marie, Montreal|Ville-Marie borough]] of downtown [[Montreal]] roughly bordered by René-Levesque Boulevard to the north, Notre-Dame Street to the south, De Bleury/Saint-Pierre Street to the east and Robert-Bourassa Boulevard to the west. The ''Palais des congrès'' (Congress Hall) building lying just east of the district is also usually comprised in it. Constructed dispersedly between 1965 and 1985 in place of older colonial housing blocks, the district underwent major [[urban renewal]] as a [[central business district]] in 2000–2003. {| align="right" width="200px" style="margin:0 0 1em 1em" |- [[File:Montreal-WTC-Square Victoria Door.png|thumb|upright|The Montreal World Trade Centre west entrance on Victoria Square.]] [[File:Montréal - Square-Victoria Metropolitan - 20050307.jpg|thumb|right|Complexe Maisonneuve and the back of Place de la Cité internationale, seen at night from Victoria Square.]] |}
==Purpose== The main purpose of the project was to restore the continuity of Montreal's downtown, broken by the gaping [[trench]] of the [[Quebec Autoroute 720|Ville-Marie Expressway]] since the 1960s, and thus to bridge the following areas: * The existing downtown business district centred on [[Place Ville Marie]] (northwest); * The [[Saint Laurent Boulevard]]/[[Sainte Catherine Street]] entertainment district and [[Chinatown, Montreal|Chinatown]] (northeast); * The historic [[Old Montreal]] district (southeast); * The [[Cité du Multimédia]] high-tech development district (southwest).
Other goals included the [[beautification]] of the [[built environment]], creation of elegant [[city square]]s, showcase of [[Quebec]] design and [[public art]], and stimulation of world-class [[real estate development]] at the heart of Montreal.
The completed area of 27 [[hectares]] (0.27 square kilometres or nearly 67 [[acre]]s), 30% of which are in the [[public domain]], spreads on an east-west axis above the Ville-Marie Expressway tunnels. It is bounded by [[Saint Urbain Street]] to the east, [[Saint Antoine Street]] to the south, [[University Street]] to the west and Viger Avenue to the north (plus [[Saint Jacques Street]] between [[McGill Street (Montreal)|McGill Street]] and [[University Street]]). The area is serviced by three stations on the [[Line 2 Orange (Montreal Metro)|Orange Line]] of the [[Montreal Metro]] and large portions of the [[Underground City, Montreal|underground city]].
==Components== The QIM itself has five main components, from east to west:
[[File:Montreal - Palais des Congrès - 20050330.jpg|thumb|left|Palais des congrès, seen from Place Jean-Paul Riopelle.]]
===Palais des congrès=== {{main|Palais des congrès de Montréal}} The Palais des congrès de Montréal (Montreal Convention Centre), the only building that was originally built over the expressway trench, was extended towards the west in the same manner, doubling in area while covering the first half of the western trench. The extension followed a similar design than the 1980s original, but with less concrete and more coloured glass, giving it a lighter appearance. The design, which included multicoloured panels and bright pink "tree" sculptures in the lobby, did not please everyone but is generally said to integrate well with the area. This section is connected to the [[Place-d'Armes (Montreal Metro)|Place-d'Armes]] Metro station.
===Place Jean-Paul Riopelle=== {{main|Place Jean-Paul Riopelle}} [[File:Jp-riopelle-joute.jpg|right|thumb|''La Joute'' on Place Jean-Paul Riopelle.]] The public square built over the trench at the same time as the Centre CDP Capital was named [[Place Jean-Paul Riopelle]] in honour of Quebec artist [[Jean-Paul Riopelle]] who died in 2002. His fountain sculpture ''[[La Joute]]'' was then moved to the square from the [[Parc Olympique]] in the district of [[Hochelaga-Maisonneuve]].
===Édifice Jacques-Parizeau=== [[File:QuartieInternational1.JPG|thumb|left|upright|Centre CDP Capital, seen from Place Jean-Paul Riopelle.]] The [[Édifice Jacques-Parizeau]] is the Montreal regional office of the [[Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec]], the main investment arm of the Quebec government. Entirely suspended over the trench, the 13-storey building was the "enabler" and is now the centrepiece of the district, stretching between Jean-Paul Riopelle and Victoria squares. Despite its strong architectural qualities, construction was marked by opposition to the huge cost overruns of an already very expensive structure, at the same time as the CDP was losing taxpayers' money from questionable investments made during the [[dot-com bubble]].
The building integrates a new [[W Hotel|W]] [[boutique hotel]] at the west end on Victoria Square, as well as headquarters of two international organisations: International Council of Graphic Design Associations (Icograda) and the International Council of Societies of Industries Design (Icsid).<ref>{{URL|http://www.icsid.org}}</ref>
===Victoria Square=== {{main| Victoria Square, Montreal}} Once an empty space crossed diagonally by Beaver Hall and McGill streets, Victoria Square was restored to its original configuration, that of a tree-lined square between parallel avenues. Trees and benches were added, the statue of [[Victoria of the United Kingdom|Queen Victoria]] was reinstated, and special care was given to [[Hector Guimard]]'s [[Art Nouveau]] outdoor entrance to the [[Square-Victoria-OACI (Montreal Metro)|Square-Victoria-OACI]] Metro station. The square is now fronted on the east by the Centre CDP Capital and the [[Montreal World Trade Centre]], to the west by [[Tour de la Bourse]] and Place de la Cité internationale, to the north by the [[Altoria|Altoria/Aimia Tower]], and to the south by the [[Quebecor]] building, its outdated façade fully re-designed for the occasion.
[[File:TourDeLaBourse night.jpg|left|upright|thumb|[[Tour de la Bourse]] (Stock Exchange Tower) near Square Victoria]]
===Place de la Cité internationale and surroundings=== [[Place de la Cité internationale]], northwest of Victoria Square, is a complex that currently consists of the [http://www.icao.int/icao/en/hq.htm headquarters] of the [[International Civil Aviation Organization]] (ICAO). The modern 17-storey building, completed in 1995, has its main entrance on the west side on [[University Street]]. A taller [http://www.emporis.com/en/wm/bu/?id=135638 second phase] has been announced on the site for quite some time, to fill the void near Tour de la Bourse.
Northwest of Victoria Square is the [[Complexe Maisonneuve]], made of the two aluminum-clad [[Bell Canada|Bell]] and [[National Bank of Canada]] towers built in 1982. Neighbouring [[Place Bonaventure]], connected to the [[Bonaventure (Montreal Metro)|Bonaventure]] Metro station, marks the western boundary of the QIM. A tunnel built under University Street between Place de la Cité internationale and Place Bonaventure finally connected the eastern and western parts of the Underground City which had previously been separated.
==Design== [[File:ICAO World Headquarters.jpg|thumb|right|ICAO World Headquarters]] Sidewalks were widened and re-paved in order to increase the pedestrian area by 40%. Open-air [[parking lot]]s were eliminated and replaced with 1,300 new parking spaces added under the Palais des Congrès, Place Jean-Paul Riopelle, and the Centre CDP Capital. Several trees were planted, and distinctive [[street furniture]] and [[street lighting]] was installed, including 22 backlit columns adorned with world flags in the median divider on University Street, welcoming southern arrivals from the [[Bonaventure Expressway]].
[[Clément Demers]] was responsible for overall project design, working with [http://www.daoustlestage.com Consortium Daoust Lestage] and Provencher, Roy et associés, with engineers [https://web.archive.org/web/20100611221214/http://www.genivar.com/ Groupe conseil Genivar]. Architect and urban planner [[:fr:Jean-Claude Marsan|Jean-Claude Marsan]] also consulted on the project.<ref>{{cite news |first=Libby |last=Ellis |title=Urban Inspiration |url=http://www.pmi.org/pathfinders/articles/N06JAN28.pdf |work=PMI Network |publisher=PMI.org |date=January 2006 |accessdate=2008-04-03 }}</ref>
As of September 2005, the project had received 22 awards in 13 different domains, including the ''PMI Project of the Year 2005'' from the [[Project Management Institute]] of [[Philadelphia]]. The project's success played a part in the decision of the [[World Anti-Doping Agency]] and [[International Design Alliance]] to move to Montreal, joining the [[International Civil Aviation Organization|ICAO]], [[International Air Transport Association|IATA]] and several other international organizations. Chef [[Normand Laprise]]'s world-famous [[Toqué!]] restaurant moved from its tiny [[Saint Denis Street]] location to the Centre CDP Capital on Place Jean-Paul Riopelle, putting the QIM on the international gastronomy map. The district has become a prestigious address for real estate development, with upscale housing built and under construction totalling approximately 1000 units as of 2005.
==Management== The project was managed by the ''Société du Quartier international de Montréal'', a [[nonprofit organization]] created in July 1999 by the federal government of Canada, province of Quebec and city of Montreal, as well as the Caisse de dépôt et placement and the ''Association des riverains du Quartier international de Montréal'' (ARQIM). The initial budget for the project was [[Canadian dollar|CAD]]$76 million (approx. US$57 million); the actual cost was $90 million (US$68 million). According to QIM's management, more than half of the overrun resulted from additional work requested by the city, as well as additional expropriation costs. Total investment in the district from all sources was approximately $860 million (US$650 million) between 2000 and 2003.
==Future projects== Current projects include the beautification of McGill Street south of Victoria Square towards Old Montreal. There are long-term plans to continue the covering of the Ville-Marie Expressway further east to the currently dilapidated [[Place Viger|Viger Square]] behind [[City hall|City Hall]], where the new land may be used for expansion of the future mega-hospital [[Centre hospitalier de l'Université de Montréal]] to be built north of the expressway.{{Citation needed|date=March 2008}}

'''Randall Rothenberg''' is a business executive, author, and former news and business reporter. Since 2007 (with a brief interruption) he has been the president and CEO of the [[Interactive Advertising Bureau]], the trade association for interactive marketing in the U.S. In 2017 Patrick Dolan assumed the role of president at the trade association.<ref>https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=39102011&privcapId=7959663&previousCapId=7959663&previousTitle=Interactive%20Advertising%20Bureau,%20Inc.</ref>
==Biography== Before joining the IAB in 2007, Rothenberg was the Senior Director of Intellectual Capital of [[Booz Allen Hamilton]], where he oversaw business development, knowledge management, and thought leadership activities, and directed the award-winning quarterly business magazine strategy+business, Strategy+Business Books, www.strategy-business.com, and other electronic and print publications published for senior business executives by [[Booz Allen]]. He has also served as the firm’s CMO.
Prior to Booz Allen, Randall spent six years at ''[[The New York Times]]'', as the technology editor and politics editor of the Sunday magazine, the daily advertising columnist, and a media and marketing reporter. For 10 years, he was a marketing and media columnist for ''[[Advertising Age]]''.
In 2010 Rothenberg briefly left the IAB to become the first [[Chief Digital Officer]] of [[Time Inc.]], in what was reported as the first major personnel move by Time's new CEO [[Jack Griffin]].<ref>Nat Ives, [http://adage.com/article/media/time-names-randall-rothenberg-chief-digital-officer/147638/ "Time Inc. Names IAB CEO Randall Rothenberg Its First Chief Digital Officer"], ''[[Advertising Age]]'', December 13, 2010.</ref> Six months later, after Time fired Griffin, Rothenberg returned to the IAB.<ref>[http://www.adweek.com/news/technology/first-mover-interview-randall-rothenberg-130609 "First Mover Interview: Randall Rothenberg. Back at the IAB, the short-time Time Inc. exec ruminates on post-modern man."] ''[[Adweek]]'', April 17, 2011.</ref>
==Books== Rothenberg wrote the 1994 book ''Where the Suckers Moon'', which discussed changes in the advertising industry, using as a case study [[Subaru]]'s problematic 1991-1993 effort to enliven its cars' staid image by engaging [[Wieden+Kennedy]], an ad agency with a reputation for "cool".<ref>[https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-17272682.html "Where the Suckers Moon: An Advertising Story" (review)], ''[[The Economist]]'', July 15, 1995 {{subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}.</ref><ref>Karen Stabiner, [http://articles.latimes.com/1994-12-22/news/ls-11625_1_suckers-moon " Endless Appetite for Success Drives the Advertising World"], ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', December 22, 1994.</ref> Rothenberg also wrote ''The Neoliberals: Creating a New American Politics'', a 1984 study of the influence of [[neoliberalism]] in the U.S. [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]].<ref>Jonathan Yardley, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/entertainment/books/1984/07/01/the-politics-and-power-plays-of-the-neoliberals/9f1a8090-3301-4ee4-a114-f0b5c3ff88ea/ "The Politics and Power Plays of the 'Neoliberals'"], ''[[The Washington Post]]'', July 1, 1984.</ref><ref>Shirley Horner, [https://www.nytimes.com/1984/08/05/nyregion/about-books.html "About Books"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', August 5, 1984.</ref>
==Personal life== Rothenberg was born to a [[American Jews|Jewish]] family<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.randallrothenberg.com/2007/11/interactive-audience-research-quest-for.html|title=Interactive Audience Research & The Quest for Truth|date=Nov 2007|author=Randall Rothenberg|quote=It was a good choice for a Jewish boy from Northeast Philly}}</ref> and received an undergraduate degree in classics from [[Princeton University]] in 1978, where he was a member of the [[Ivy Club]].<ref>Randall Rothenberg, [https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/04/nyregion/an-old-club-breaks-bread-and-a-tradition-crumbles.html "An Old Club Breaks Bread, and a Tradition Crumbles"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', May 4, 1991.</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} [[Image:Unclesamwantyou.jpg|thumb|This World War I recruitment poster by [[James Montgomery Flagg]], with more than four million copies printed in 1917 and 1918, defined not only an Army recruiting slogan, but also [[Uncle Sam]]'s image for years to come.<ref name="loc">{{cite web|url=https://www.loc.gov/exhibits/treasures/trm015.html|title=The Most Famous Poster|work=American Treasures of the Library of Congress}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.livescience.com/mysteries/080630-uncle-sam.html | title=Who Created Uncle Sam? | publisher=Live Science | work=Life's Little Mysteries | accessdate=16 February 2012 | archivedate=3 December 2008 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081203113644/http://www.livescience.com/mysteries/080630-uncle-sam.html}}</ref>]] [[File:U.S. Army advertisement - "Be All You Can Be" (May 1986).webm|thumb|U.S. Army TV advertisement from 1986 using the "Be All You Can Be!" slogan]] '''Slogans of the [[United States Army]]''' changed rarely in the 20th century, relative to the 21st.
==World War I== '''"I Want YOU for US Army"''' featured on a poster of [[Uncle Sam]] painted by [[James Montgomery Flagg]].
==1950s–1971== '''"Look Sharp, Be Sharp, Go Army!"''' was a recruiting slogan in the 1950s and 1960s. [[The Big Picture (TV series)|The Big Picture]], public announcements on broadcast television, and highway roadway signs advertised the slogan during a time of a national draft of young men 18 to 34 years of age. The advantage of volunteering for service as opposed to being drafted was the option to choose which career field you wanted to serve in along with the first unit and/or location of assignment.
==1971 to 1980== '''"Today's Army Wants to Join You"''' was a recruiting slogan from the 1971 Volunteer Army (Project VOLAR) campaign, which was introduced as the country prepared to transition to an [[All-volunteer force|all-volunteer]] military. When N. W. Ayer & Son, who were engaged by the US Army, believed they felt the army said "Today's Army is changing; we want to meet you half way", the firm came up with that slogan. General [[William Westmoreland]] asked "Do we have to ask it that way?" but agreed to the campaign. The slogan was replaced by "Join the People Who've Joined the Army" in 1973, which later evolved into "This is the Army."<ref>pp.141–142 Griffith, Robert K. & Wyndham, John ''U.S Army's Transition to the All Volunteer Force 1868–1974'' 1997 DIANE Publishing</ref>
Slogan was written in 1971 by Ted Regan Jr., Executive Vice President and Executive Creative Director of N.W. Ayer, the Army's ad agency. Regan also wrote the follow up slogan, "Join the people who've joined the Army."
==1980 to 2001== '''"Be All You Can Be"''' was the recruiting slogan of the United States Army for over twenty years.<ref>AdSlogans.com - Wise Words/13 Archived 19 December 2010 at WebCite</ref> [[E. N. J. Carter|Earl Carter]] (pen-name, E.N.J. Carter) working for the N.W. Ayer Advertising Agency as a Senior Copywriter created the “Be All You Can Be” theme line in 1980.<ref>“America’s Army”, Beth Bailey, Pages 191, 192</ref> In January 2003, the U.S. Army awarded Carter its Outstanding Civilian Service Award.<ref>http://earlcarterawards.com/armypressrelease.pdf Archived 19 December 2010 at WebCite</ref> Carter’s original concept sheet, with words “Be All You Can Be”, is now part of a permanent collection at the US Army Heritage Center Foundation.
==2001 to 2006== [[File:Humvee with United States Army slogan.JPG|thumb|A [[Humvee]] [[Wrap advertising|wrapped]] with the slogan in April 2006]] {{anchor|army_of_one}}'''"Army of One"''' was a relatively short-lived recruiting slogan. It replaced the popular "Be All You Can Be" and was replaced in 2006 by the new slogan "Army Strong".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/11/21/AR2006112101295.html|title=Army Debuts New Slogan in Recruiting Commercials|last=Tyson|first=Anne Scott|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=2012-06-12|date=22 November 2006}}</ref> The reason for the replacement, states [[Frank Luntz]], is that the slogan "Army of One" is contrary to the idea of [[teamwork]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Luntz|first1=Frank|title=Words That Work|isbn=9781401385750|page=119|quote=Why did the U.S. Army jettison "be all that you can be," surely one of the most widely known taglines in the world, for the rather odd and uninspiring "An army of one"? Especially when an "army," by definition, is more than one person. While it is understandable for an organization like the military to want to individualize and personalize what it does, that's just not a believable or credible selling point.}}</ref> It is unknown whether this slogan was taken directly from the poster for the 1976 [[Clint Eastwood]] film ''[[The Outlaw Josey Wales]]'', which had "An Army of One" under a drawing of the Josey Wales character.
==2006 to present== [[File:Army Strong (2006).webm|thumb|The "Army Strong" advertising campaign's debut video, released in October 2006.]] '''"Army Strong"''' is the [[Military recruitment|recruiting]] [[slogan]] that has been used for more than a decade by the [[United States Army]]. The composer of the music used in the Army Strong television commercials is [[Mark Isham]].<ref>[http://www.army.mil/-news/2006/11/09/568-the-making-of-army-strong/ The making of "Army Strong"]</ref>
==See also== *[[United States Armed Forces]]

{{redirect-distinguish|Solar road|SolaRoad}} '''Smart highway''' and '''smart road''' are terms for a number of different proposals to incorporate technologies into roads for generating [[solar energy]], for improving the operation of [[autonomous car]]s, for lighting, and for monitoring the condition of the road.
== Vehicle infrastructure integration == {{Further|Platoon (automobile)|Vehicle infrastructure integration}}
== Structural health monitoring == {{Main|Structural health monitoring}}
== Intelligent transportation systems == {{Main|Intelligent transportation system}} {{See also|Virginia Smart Road}}
''Intelligent transportation systems'' usually refers to the use of information and communication technologies (rather than innovations in the construction of the roadway) in the field of road transport, including infrastructure, vehicles and users, and in traffic management and mobility management, as well as for interfaces with other modes of transport.<ref>http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:L:2010:207:0001:0013:EN:PDF</ref>
== Photovoltaic pavement == Photovoltaic pavement is a form of pavement that generates electricity by collecting [[solar power]] with [[photovoltaics]].<ref>{{cite journal|author=Matej Lufčić|author2=Marina Maras|author3=Mario Vukelić|title=Energy Saving Design and Materials in Road Transport|url=http://bib.irb.hr/datoteka/540022.Energy_saving_design_and_materials_in_road_transport.doc|accessdate=23 May 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140524041829/http://bib.irb.hr/datoteka/540022.Energy_saving_design_and_materials_in_road_transport.doc|archivedate=24 May 2014|df=}}</ref> Parking lots, footpaths, driveways, streets and highways are all candidate locations where this material could be used.
In 2013 Students at the Solar Institute at George Washington University installed a solar panel walking path designed by [[Onyx Solar]], something they call ''solar pavement''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://inhabitat.com/students-install-the-worlds-first-solar-pavement-panels-in-virginia/ |title=Students Install the World's First Solar Pavement Panels in Virginia | Inhabitat - Sustainable Design Innovation, Eco Architecture, Green Building |publisher=Inhabitat |accessdate=2014-06-02 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140531095151/http://inhabitat.com/students-install-the-worlds-first-solar-pavement-panels-in-virginia/ |archivedate=2014-05-31 |df= }}</ref>
''[[SolaRoad]]'' is a system being developed by the [[Netherlands Organisation for Applied Scientific Research]] (TNO), the [[Ooms Groep]], [[Imtech]] and the Netherlands province of [[North Holland]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.solaroad.nl/|title=SolaRoad website|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140606205735/http://www.solaroad.nl/ |archivedate=2014-06-06|df=}}</ref> They plan to install their panels on 100 m of cycle path in [[Krommenie]], [[Netherlands]] in November 2014.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://inhabitat.com/the-netherlands-to-pave-roads-with-solaroad-solar-panels/ |title=The Netherlands to Pave Roads with Solaroad Solar Panels | Inhabitat - Sustainable Design Innovation, Eco Architecture, Green Building |publisher=Inhabitat |date=2012-05-23 |accessdate=2014-06-02 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140426110537/http://inhabitat.com/the-netherlands-to-pave-roads-with-solaroad-solar-panels/ |archivedate=2014-04-26 |df= }}</ref> A variant concept of a "solar road" installed in [[Avenhorn]], by Ooms Avenhorn Holding AV, uses asphalt and tarmac to absorb the sun’s rays and heat water for use in domestic heating.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ecmag.com/section/miscellaneous/dutch-company-drives-new-solar-power|title=Dutch Company Drives New Solar Power|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140527214130/http://www.ecmag.com/section/miscellaneous/dutch-company-drives-new-solar-power|archivedate=2014-05-27|df=}}</ref>
The [[Solar Roadways]] company of Idaho, USA, is developing a prototype system to replace current roads, parking lots, and driveways with photovoltaic solar road panels that generate [[electricity]].<ref name="Solar Roadways">[http://singularityhub.com/2014/05/22/following-the-solar-brick-road-to-clean-energy-and-smart-roadways/ Following the Solar Brick Road] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140524004212/http://singularityhub.com/2014/05/22/following-the-solar-brick-road-to-clean-energy-and-smart-roadways/ |date=2014-05-24 }} singularityhub.com</ref>
[[South Korea]] has built a freeway with the median covered by solar panels above a bikepath.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.techtimes.com/articles/72306/20150727/daejeon-sejong-bike-highway-solar-powered-good-environment.htm |title = The Daejeon-Sejong Bike Highway Is Solar Powered And Good For The Environment |last = Reich |first = J.E. |date = July 27, 2015 |website = Tech Times |publisher = |access-date = 2016-11-02 |quote = The solar panels are used to power the lights that line the highway proper, as well as ... electric car chargers. |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20161104002413/http://www.techtimes.com/articles/72306/20150727/daejeon-sejong-bike-highway-solar-powered-good-environment.htm |archivedate = November 4, 2016 |df = }}</ref>
The first photovoltaic road in the world was constructed in [[Tourouvre]], [[Orne]], France in 2016.<ref> {{cite web | url = | title = France gets a step closer to solar roads | last = Tsagas | first = Ilias | date = August 4, 2016 | website = PV Magazine Global | publisher = | access-date = 2016-11-02 | quote = ...the product is based on crystalline silicon, and although it is very thin, ... it is also “very sturdy, skid-resistant and designed to last,” with the durability to bear all types of vehicles, including trucks.}}</ref><ref name="sudestsegoleneroyallance">{{cite news|last1=Bourgin|first1=Yohann|title=High Tech. Ségolène Royal lance la première route solaire dans l'Orne|url=http://www.ouest-france.fr/environnement/amenagement-du-territoire/high-tech-segolene-royal-lance-la-premiere-route-solaire-dans-l-orne-4582630|accessdate=November 2, 2016|work=[[Sud-Ouest (newspaper)|Sud-Ouest]]|date=October 25, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161028223847/http://www.ouest-france.fr/environnement/amenagement-du-territoire/high-tech-segolene-royal-lance-la-premiere-route-solaire-dans-l-orne-4582630|archivedate=October 28, 2016|df=}}</ref> Called "Wattway", it was built by [[Société Nouvelle Aeracem]] (SNA), and dedicated by the French Minister of Ecology, [[Ségolène Royal]] on October 25, 2016.<ref name="sudestsegoleneroyallance"/> The 1-km section of road opened to traffic on 22 December 2016.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/dec/22/solar-panel-road-tourouvre-au-perche-normandy |title=World's first solar panel road opens in Normandy village |work=[[The Guardian]] |author=Kim Willsher |date=December 22, 2016 |accessdate=December 23, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161222204933/https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/dec/22/solar-panel-road-tourouvre-au-perche-normandy |archivedate=December 22, 2016 |df= }}</ref> It is believed the road will provide enough power for the town's streetlights.
The [[Jinan]] solar highway opened in China in December 2017 along a 1.2 mile stretch. It uses [[transparent concrete]] on the top layer with the solar panels underneath. It was the second solar roadway in the city, the first opened in September 2017 using a different technology.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://electrek.co/2017/12/21/china-solar-roadways-transparent-concrete-solar-cells-charge-cars/ |title=China is building solar roadways – ‘transparent concrete’ atop solar cells that charge driving cars |work=Electrek |author=John Fitzgerald Weaver |date=December 21, 2017 |accessdate=January 15, 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180116135255/https://electrek.co/2017/12/21/china-solar-roadways-transparent-concrete-solar-cells-charge-cars/ |archivedate=January 16, 2018 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://cleantechnica.com/2017/12/30/china-opens-1-kilometer-long-solar-road/ |title=China Opens 1-Kilometer Long Solar Road |work=CleanTechnica |author=Steve Hanley |date=December 30, 2017 |accessdate=January 15, 2018}}</ref>
===Solar Road Panels=== The main purpose of solar roadways is to replace asphalt roads with Solar Panels which generate energy through the sun that can be used by local houses or businesses that are connected to the system from either the house’s driveway or the businesses parking lot. The panels will also increase the number of charging stations for electric cars if that station is connected to the solar roadway. Each panel is roughly 12’ by 12’ of interlocking panels that have their own LED lights that will be used as the road lines, and can also be used to spell out words like “Reduce Speed” or “Traffic Ahead” to help the flow of traffic.<ref name = Ranjan>{{cite journal|last1=Ranjan|first1=Rajeev|title=Solar Power Roads: Revitalising Solar Highways, Electrical Power and Smart Grids|journal=International Journal of Engineering Research and General Science|date=January–February 2015|volume=3|issue=1|pages=380–385}}</ref>
There are 3 layers that make up the solar panels:
1. The Road Surface Layer - The Road Layer is the High Strength layer that has the photovoltaic cells which attracts the sun’s rays, it has traction so vehicles don’t slide off the road, and it’s waterproof to protect the layers below.<ref name = Ranjan/>
2. The Electronic Layer - The Electronic Layers contain a mini microprocessor board that helps control the heating element of the panels, this technology can help melt the snow that lands on the panels so that hazardous road conditions will no longer be an issue in the more northern regions. This layer can sense how much weight is on the panels and can control the heating element to melt the snow.<ref name = Ranjan/>
3. The Base Plate Layer - The Base Plate Layer is the layer that collects the energy from the sun and distributes the power to the homes or businesses that are connected to the solar roadways. This will also be used to transfer the energy to cars as they drive over the strip to recharge the battery.<ref name = Ranjan/>
===Criticism=== ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' magazine stated that solar roadways would produce less electricity than solar cells that are placed at an angle, and that less light would touch them because of shade, dirt covering the road, and cars blocking the sun from touching the panels. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/health_and_science/science/2017/12/solar_roads_are_almost_definitely_not_the_future.html|title=What Is the Point of a Solar Road?|first=Neel V.|last=Patel|date=December 28, 2017|publisher=|via=Slate}}</ref>
Critics have pointed out that solar roadways would be both more expensive, and less productive than more conventional ways of combining solar power with infrastructure, such as building shelters over roads and parking areas and putting traditional solar panels on the roofs; [[Elon Musk]] demonstrated that there is ample space in the US, apart from roads, to fulfill the power requirements of the country.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.equities.com/news/elon-musk-demonstrates-why-solar-roadways-would-be-really-silly|title=Elon Musk Demonstrates Why Solar Roadways Would be Really Silly|last=equities.com|work=Equities.com|access-date=2018-09-05|language=en-US}}</ref> . <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://interestingengineering.com/solar-roadways-engineering-failure|title=Solar Roadways: An Engineering FAILURE|date=2017-05-18|access-date=2018-09-05|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dvhn.nl/drenthe/Parkeren-onder-zonnepanelen-bij-TT-Circuit-21255430.html|title=Cookiemelding - DVHN.nl|website=www.dvhn.nl}}</ref>
===Smart pavement=== The Missouri Department of Transportation (MoDOT) began testing out “smart pavement” at a rest stop outside of Conway, Missouri along historic Route 66 late in 2016. The pilot program currently covers about 200 square feet of sidewalk at the visitor center and cost $100,000 (Landers), largely subsidized by the Federal Highway Administration.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cronkleton|first1=Robert A.|title=Missouri’s solar roadways to begin with sidewalk at historic Route 66 Welcome Center|url=http://www.kansascity.com/news/local/article93755517.html|accessdate=20 April 2017|agency=Kansas City Star|date=August 4, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170511125201/http://www.kansascity.com/news/local/article93755517.html|archivedate=11 May 2017|df=}}</ref> It’s all part of Missouri’s Road to Tomorrow initiative to find new innovations in their transportation infrastructure. Missouri wants to take advantage of these roadways to implement other, related technologies. The panels will heat the road and keep snow and ice from accumulating. They will also feature LED diodes that will increase the visibility of road lines. The LEDs would also double in helping prevent paint from inhibiting solar power generation.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Landers|first1=Jay|title=Missouri to Test Solar Roadways, Smart Pavement as Part of Road to Tomorrow Project|journal=Civil Engineering—ASCE|date=2016|volume=86|issue=9|pages=30–31|url=http://cedb.asce.org/CEDBsearch/record.jsp?dockey=0352321|accessdate=20 April 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170504172325/http://cedb.asce.org/CEDBsearch/record.jsp?dockey=0352321|archivedate=4 May 2017|df=}}</ref> The panels have not had enough time to determine durability, energy efficiency, or cost effectiveness in a real world sense yet, so MoDOT has not reach any conclusions about feasibility and future application yet.
==Wireless vehicle charging== {{See|In-road electric vehicle charger|Inductive charging|Wireless power transfer}}
The [[Online Electric Vehicle]] being developed by [[KAIST]] (the  Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology) has electrical circuits built into the road which will power suitably adapted vehicles via contactless [[electromagnetic induction]]. A pilot system powering electric buses is under development. Germany's [[IAV#In-road electric vehicle charger|IAV]] is another company that is developing induction chargers.
===Electromechanical batteries=== Roadway-powered electric vehicle system is the patent held by Howard R. Ross. It has several components. The first of which is an all electric vehicle that would be fit with electromechanical batteries that accept a charge from the road. The road is the second component and would have strategically placed charging coils as to only charge the car when needed. These cars and roads would not require gas or solar power.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ross|first1=H.R.|title=Roadway-Powered Electric Vehicle System|url=https://www.google.com/patents/US5669470|website=Google Patents}}</ref>
Nowhere in the world is an invention like this currently implemented, and this is due to the cost of the infrastructure overhaul that would be needed to bring this patent into reality.
== Road markings == [[File:Glowing Lines Roosegaarde.jpg|thumb|Glowing Lines, Studio Roosegaarde]] The ''Smart Highway'' concept developed by [[Studio Roosegaarde]] and the infrastructure management group [[Heijmans]] in the Netherlands incorporated [[Photoluminescence|photo-luminescent]] paint for road markings, which absorb light during the day then glow for up to 10 hours. The technology was demonstrated on a stretch of highway in [[North Brabant|Brabant]], Netherlands.<ref>{{cite web |last=Clark |first=Liat |url=https://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2012-10/30/smart-highway-glows-in-the-dark |title=Netherlands highways will glow in the dark from mid-2013 (Wired UK) |publisher=Wired.co.uk |accessdate=2014-06-02 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140530095727/http://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2012-10/30/smart-highway-glows-in-the-dark |archivedate=2014-05-30 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-27021291 |title=Glow in the dark road unveiled in the Netherlands |publisher=BBC |date=2014-04-14 |accessdate=2014-06-21 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140703073055/http://www.bbc.com/news/technology-27021291 |archivedate=2014-07-03 |df= }}</ref>
== Frost protection and melting snow, ice == [[Snowmelt system]]s using electricity or hot water to heat roads and pavements have been installed in various locations.
[[Solar Roadways]] has proposed including a snowmelt system with their photovoltaic road panels since the panels already have electrical power connections for harvesting photovoltaic power.<ref>[http://www.cnn.com/2011/TECH/innovation/01/19/smart.roads/ "Solar-powered 'smart' roads could zap snow, ice"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170204050905/http://www.cnn.com/2011/TECH/innovation/01/19/smart.roads/ |date=2017-02-04 }}, Thom Patterson. CNN. January 19, 2011. Retrieved 8 feb 2017</ref> Skeptics point to the energy requirements.<ref name="Z">[http://www.zeroto60times.com/2016/06/solar-powered-roads-future/ "Solar Powered Roads: The Future, or Just Hype?"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211081821/http://www.zeroto60times.com/2016/06/solar-powered-roads-future/|date=2017-02-11}}, Andy Jensen. Zero to 60 Times. June 2016. Retrieved 8 feb 2017</ref>
ICAX Limited of London's "Interseasonal Heat Capture" technology captures solar energy in thermal banks and releases it back under a roadway, heating it and keeping asphalt free of ice.<ref>[http://www.icax.co.uk/toddington_results.html "Independent results published by TRL on Toddington ice clearing demonstration using Interseasonal Heat Transfer™ to heat roads"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161219074315/http://icax.co.uk/toddington_results.html |date=2016-12-19 }}, ICAX. April 2008. Retrieved 8 feb 2017</ref>

[[File:James Speyer.jpg|thumb|[[James Speyer]] (1861–1941)]] [[File:Sir Edgar Speyer.jpg|thumb|Sir [[Edgar Speyer]] (1862–1932)]] [[File:Sir Edgar & Lady Leonora Speyer circa 1921.jpg|thumb|Sir Edgar & Lady Speyer, {{abbr|c.|circa}} 1921]] The '''Speyer family''' is a prominent [[Ashkenazi Jews|Jewish]] family of [[Germans|German descent]]. It can be traced back to Michael Isaac Speyer (1644–1692), who had briefly been the head of the Jewish community in [[Frankfurt am Main]] in 1691–92. The family originates from [[Speyer]] in [[Palatinate (region)|Palatinate]], hence the surname.<ref>Prominent Families of New York, The Historical company, New York, 1897</ref> In the late eighteenth century, the Speyers were the wealthiest Jewish family in Frankfurt, well above the [[Rothschild family]].<ref>[http://www.leannelangley.co.uk/documents/BankerBaronetSaviourSpy.pdf Leanne Langley: Banker, Baronet, Saviour, ‘Spy’: Sir Edgar Speyer and the Queen’s Hall Proms, 1902-14]</ref>
==Business activities== The patriarch of the family, Joseph Lazard Speyer, took over the ''Ellissen'' bank, inherited from his wife Jette Ellissen, and renamed it to ''J. L. Speyer-Elissen'' in 1818.<ref>[http://www.artfact.com/auction-lot/yiddish-german-correspondence-between-two-jewish-102-c-3f284c3533 Yiddish-German Correspondence between Two Jewish-German Banks]</ref> When their son, Lazard Joseph, got to the helm of the family business in 1838, the name was changed to [[Lazard Speyer-Ellissen]].
In 1837 Lazard Joseph's brother Philipp left Frankfurt am Main for [[New York City]] and established there in 1845 [[Speyer & Co.|Philipp Speyer & Co.]] (after Philipp´s death in 1876 renamed [[Speyer & Co.]]). His brother Gustav (1825–1883) joined him to set up Philipp Speyer & Co.<ref>Wilkins, Mira: „The History of Foreign Investment in the United States to 1914“, Harvard University Press, London 1989, S.99, {{ISBN|978-0674396661}}</ref> but in 1861 Gustav formed [[Speyer Brothers]] in [[London]]. Early to realize the potential in [[North America]], the Speyer family was one of the top five issuers of [[United States]] and [[Mexico|Mexican]] railroad securities by the 1870s, their nearest rivals being [[Kuhn, Loeb & Co.]] and [[J.P. Morgan & Co.]]<ref>[http://www.leannelangley.co.uk/documents/BankerBaronetSaviourSpy.pdf Leanne Langley: Banker, Baronet, Saviour, ‘Spy’: Sir Edgar Speyer and the Queen’s Hall Proms, 1902-14]</ref>
The London branch of the Speyer business, Speyer Brothers, was liquidated in 1922, when Gustav´s son [[Edgar Speyer]] left the [[United Kingdom]] for the United States. The Frankfurt branch, Lazard Speyer-Ellissen, was dissolved in 1934, shortly after the ''[[Machtergreifung]]'', the coming into power of the [[National Socialist German Workers' Party]].<ref>{{cite book |title=Zwischen Marktwirtschaft und Dirigismus : Bankenpolitik im "Dritten Reich" 1933–1939 |first=Christopher |last=Kopper |location=Bonn |publisher=Bouvier |year=1995 |isbn=3-416-02529-6 |page=246 |language=de}}</ref> The Frankfurt family home, the prominent [[:de:Villa Kennedy|Villa Speyer]], was taken away by the [[National Socialist]]s in 1938.<ref>[http://pbof.com/villakennedy History of the Villa Speyer in Frankfurt, today a Grand Hotel]</ref>
In 1938, James Speyer retired and decided to close Speyer & Co. in New York rather than let his name continue with the remaining partners. Therefore, the last of the three Speyer banking branches was liquidated in 1939.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=lbpDH6likNAC&pg=PT266 Susie J. Pak: "Gentleman Bankers - The world of J.P. Morgan", Harvard Studies in Business History (Book 51) 2013] {{ISBN|978-0-674-07303-6}}</ref>
The Speyer family belonged to Frankfurt’s patrons and made considerable foundations to support science and scientific education. Their funds provided the basis for the [[University of Frankfurt am Main]].
==Family tree== {{Tree list}} *Joseph Lazard Speyer (1783–1846), married to Jette Ellissen **Lazard Joseph Speyer (1810–1876), married his cousin Therese Ellissen (1808-?) in 1832 ***{{Interlanguage link multi|Georg Speyer|de}} (1835–1902), banker, married {{Interlanguage link multi|Franziska Gumbert|de}} (1844-1909) in 1869 ****{{Tree list/final branch}} Alfred Julius Speyer (1871–1927) ***{{Tree list/final branch}} Jaques Robert Speyer (1837-1876), married Sophie Emilie Cassel (1843-?) **[[Philipp Speyer]] (1815–1876), emigrated to the [[United States]] in 1837 and established in 1845 the New York branch, [[Speyer & Co.|Philipp Speyer & Co.]]<ref>{{cite journal |last=Supple |first=Barry E. |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=1957 |month= |title=A Business Elite: German-Jewish Financiers in Nineteenth-Century New York |journal=Business History Review |volume=31 |issue=2 |pages=143–178 |jstor= 3111848 }}</ref> (1876 renamed [[Speyer & Co.]]). Married in 1850 Charlotte Stern (1824-1906), daughter of [[Jacob Samuel Hayum Stern]] (1780-1833), the founder of the Bank [[Jacob S.H. Stern]] in [[Frankfurt am Main]]. ***Helene Therese Speyer (1857–1898), married Paul Meyer (1844–1925), a German railway manager ***{{Tree list/final branch}} Anna Emilie Speyer (1861–1940), married 1885 {{ill|Arthur von Gwinner|de}} (1856–1931), member of the [[Vorstand]] of the [[Deutsche Bank]] **{{Tree list/final branch}} [[Gustav Speyer]] (1825–1883), followed his brother to the US, joined [[Speyer & Co.]] in 1845 and set up [[Speyer Brothers]] 1861 in [[London]] *** [[James Speyer]] (1861–1941), senior partner at [[Speyer & Co.]] since 1899, married to [[Ellin Prince Speyer|Ellin Lowery]] (1849–1921) *** [[Edgar Speyer]] (1862–1932), moved to London in 1887,<ref>{{cite web | ref=Reference-ONDB |url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/36215 |title= Speyer, Sir Edgar, baronet (1862–1932) |accessdate=4 September 2015 |last= Barker |first=Theo |authorlink=Theo Barker |year= 2004 |work= [[Dictionary of National Biography#Oxford Dictionary of National Biography|Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]] |publisher= [[Oxford University Press]] |doi= 10.1093/ref:odnb/36215}}</ref> married to [[Leonora Speyer|Leonora von Stosch]] (1872–1956) ***{{Tree list/final branch}} Hanna Louise Speyer (called Lucie, 1870–1918), married 1892 [[Eduard Beit von Speyer]] (nobled in 1910, 1860–1933), cousin of [[Alfred Beit]] (1853–1906) ****[[Herbert Beit von Speyer]] (1899–1961) ****[[Erwin Eduard von Speyer]] (1893–1914) ****[[Hedwig Johanna Henriette von Speyer]] (1896–1966) ****{{Tree list/final branch}} [[Ellin Anna von Speyer]] (1903–1983) <!-- Wife or sister: **** Ellin Beit von Speyer (1903–1983) --> {{Tree list/end}}

''The Fall of the House of Speyer: The Story of a Banking Dynasty'' (I.B. Tauris, 2015) xii + 244 pp. {{ISBN|978-1-78453-176-8}}. [http://eh.net/?s=speyer online review]

'''C. Turney Stevens, Jr.,''' (born c. 1950) is the dean [[emeritus]] of the College of Business at [[Lipscomb University]], a [[Private school|private]] [[Christian]] [[university]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]].<ref name="profile">[http://www.lipscomb.edu/www/bio/detail/1882 Faculty profile], Lipscomb University, retrieved 2016-02-26.</ref>
Stevens was himself an alumnus of Lipscomb, graduating in 1972, and he earned an [[MBA]] at [[Vanderbilt University]] in 1981. He worked as an investment banker for 35 years; he has cited [[Joe M. Rodgers]] (for whom he served as president of Rodgers Capital) as a mentor.<ref>{{citation|title=Executive profile: NBJ talks with Turney Stevens|journal=Nashville Business Journal|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/nashville/stories/2004/10/18/smallb4.html|date=October 17, 2004}}.</ref> He also founded several Nashville-based companies including magazine publisher PlusMedia and investment bank Harpeth Capital.<ref>{{citation|url=http://nashvillepost.com/news/2007/10/26/harpeth_companies_ceo_stevens_retires|journal=[[Nashville Post]]|date=October 26, 2007|first=Walker|last=Duncan|title=Harpeth Companies CEO Stevens retires}}.</ref> Stevens joined the Lipscomb faculty in 2007, after his retirement from Harpeth,<ref>{{citation|url=http://nashvillepost.com/news/2007/12/20/people_former_harpeth_cos_ceo_stevens_to_join_lipscomb_faculty|journal=[[Nashville Post]]|date=December 20, 2007|title=People: Former Harpeth Cos. CEO Stevens to join Lipscomb faculty}}.</ref> and became dean in 2008.<ref>{{citation|url=http://nashvillepost.com/news/2008/3/26/former_harpeth_ceo_to_lead_lipscomb_business_school|journal=[[Nashville Post]]|date=March 26, 2008|first=Walker|last=Duncan|title=Former Harpeth CEO to lead Lipscomb business school: Alum joined faculty last December}}.</ref><ref>{{citation|title=Stevens takes over as dean of business school at Lipscomb|journal=[[The Tennessean]]|first=Wendy|last=Lee|date=March 26, 2008}}.</ref>
As dean, Stevens created the Dean Institute for Corporate Governance and Integrity,<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.businessweek.com/smallbiz/content/dec2008/sb20081230_999118.htm|journal=[[BusinessWeek]]|title=Making the Case for Business Ethics: Turney Stevens, dean of Lipscomb's College of Business, explains why it's important for leaders of small companies to do the right thing|date=December 30, 2008|first=Karen E.|last=Klein}}.</ref> founded a student ethics program with the support of the Center for Public Trust,<ref>{{citation|title = Lipscomb gets student ethics program|date = December 28, 2009|journal = [[The Tennessean]]}}.</ref> established a lecture series featuring ethical business people, and offered ethics training to local corporate leaders. On the basis of these activities, ''[[Ethisphere]]'' magazine named him as one of "2009's 100 most influential people in business ethics".<ref>{{citation|url=http://ethisphere.com/2009s-100-most-influential-people-in-business-ethics/|journal=Ethisphere|title=2009's 100 most influential people in business ethics|date=December 16, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100106134839/http://ethisphere.com/2009s-100-most-influential-people-in-business-ethics/|archivedate=January 6, 2010|df=}}.</ref><ref>{{citation|title=Nashville People in Business|journal=[[The Tennessean]]|date=January 10, 2010}}.</ref><ref>{{citation|url=http://www.lipscomb.edu/filter.asp?SID=14&co_key=17169|title=Ethisphere names Dean Turney Stevens one of business ethics most influential people|publisher=[[Lipscomb University]]|accessdate=2011-05-29}}.</ref><ref>{{citation|url=http://nashvillepost.com/blogs/postbusiness/2010/1/5/lipscomb_dean_named_to_biz_ethics_list|journal=[[Nashville Post]]|date=January 5, 2010|first=Geert|last=De Lombaerde|title=Lipscomb dean named to biz ethics list}}.</ref> In 2014, Stevens moved into an emeritus role, focusing on fundraising for the college.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.lipscomb.edu/news/archive/detail/61/28108 | title = Stevens becomes College of Business dean emeritus | website = Lipscomb University | access-date = 2016-02-26 }}</ref>

[[File: Valentin Dikul 2.jpg|thumb]] '''Valentin Ivanovich Dikul''' ({{lang-ru|Валентин Иванович Дикуль}}; born 3 April 1948 in [[Kaunas|Kaunas, Lithuanian]] SSR, Soviet Union) is a circus artist, head of the Russian medical and rehabilitation center of the [[Musculoskeletal disorder|musculoskeletal system diseases]]. [[People's Artist of Russia]] (1999).<ref name="786-1999">[http://pravo.levonevsky.org/bazaru09/ukaz/sbor09/text09390.htm 7 июня 1999 года]</ref>
== Biography == Born in Kaunas prematurely, weighing just over one kilogram. His father Ivan G. (1920-1950) was shot dead by bandits when he was 30 years old, and his mother Anna Korneevna (1925-1952), died at age 27 when Valentin was still in kindergarten.<ref name="КТ">[http://www.peoples.ru/sport/heavy_atlete/dikul/ Никогда не сдавайся]</ref> He was raised by his grandparents until he was seven years old. At the age of seven, he began living in orphanages, first in Vilnius, then - in Kaunas. At nine years old, he became interested in the circus and helped to put up the circus tent, cleaning the arena, looking after the animals, sweeping, washing the floors.
At fourteen he began working as a motorcycle repairman. He also engaged in gymnastics, wrestling, weightlifting, balancing acts, acrobatics, juggling, stunts and invented tricks. He contacted the circus circle in Kaunas.<ref name="КТ"/>
=== Injury === In 1962, when Valentin was almost fifteen, he starred in his first act of air gymnastics at the Sports Palace. The act was performed at an altitude of 13 meters.<ref name="КТ"/> During one such performance, a steel support cross beam suddenly broke, and Valentin fell from 13 meters. He spent a week in intensive care at the City Hospital and was then transferred to the neurosurgery department of the hospital. His final diagnosis was a compression fracture of the lumbar spine and traumatic brain injury, with many local fractures.<ref name="КТ"/>
=== Recovery === Dikul began to train. Lifted objects, stretched rubber bands and performed push-ups. He worked for 5–6 hours a day, but his legs did not work. Suffering from pain in the spine and fatigue, he performed strength exercises and studied the medical literature on the spine, gathering the necessary information. Doctors asked him to stop wasting time and effort, explaining that success is impossible. But he continued to exhaustion. He began to lift weights small at first, then more and more increasing the weight, developing all the muscles of the back which he was able to. Then he had the idea that you need to move the inactive parts of the body as if they were healthy a full cycle<ref name="ПЛ"/>. Tied a rope to his feet, passing it under the headboard, which played the role of the pulley and then pulling it and moving the feet. Then he began using counterweight loads. Friends helped him build a system of weights and pulleys around his bed designed by Dikul. Eight months later he was discharged from the hospital with the first group of disability.<ref name="КТ"/>
A series of publications in the press provoked an avalanche of letters to Dikul with requests for help. In response, he would send them a package of instructions designed for medical rehabilitation. In processing a large amount of correspondence he was helped by his wife Lyudmila.
Many people confined to a wheelchair, saw it as their hope. Valentin spent three to four hours a day on advising people with disabilities.<ref name="ПЛ">[http://paralife.narod.ru/1rehabilitation/volin/bragg_nishi_dikul_4.htm Система Валентина Дикуля]</ref>
A Russian rehabilitation center for patients with spinal injuries and with consequences of infantile cerebral paralysis was opened in 1988 called Dikul Center.<ref name="ПЛ"/>
